ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MIDDLE-AGE WORKING ADULTS

(Incentive package to look after aged parents)

     1.  Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports what is the possibility of the introduction of a comprehensive incentive package for the middle-class, middle-income, middle-age working adults, especially singles, to look after their aged parents similar to the comprehensive marriage and procreation package for parents.

     The Minister of State for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon) (for the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in Singapore, the family is the cornerstone of support for the elderly. Family ties are strong. From the 2003 Survey on Social Attitudes of Singaporeans, 98% of Singaporeans felt that they had the duty to give financial support to their family members.  99% of Singaporeans also agreed that children should regularly spend time

Column: 422

with their elderly parents, and about 87% of the elderly in Singapore live with their families.  These figures show a strong sense of filial piety, and a belief in family being the first line of support.

 

     On its part, the Government puts in place various measures to help families take care of their elderly members.  We serve as a facilitator, and provide support in a few ways:  first, by introducing financial measures to alleviate the burden of caring for elderly parents;  second, by working with the Voluntary Welfare Organisations (VWOs) to ensure adequate provision of services that elderly persons need; and, third, by providing various forms of support services for caregivers.

 

     With regard to financial measures, the Government has focused its limited resources on the needy and low-income, rather than the middle-income.  This is as it should be, as the needy are the ones who need help most.  Nevertheless, the Government has also put in place various financial measures, such as tax relief and reduced foreign domestic worker levy to help relieve the load on families who care for their elderly members.  Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, in his Budget Speech, has announced more help for families in this aspect.  Medisave top-ups will be given to all adult Singaporeans, the largest share of $350 going to senior citizens aged 60 and above.  To help older Singaporeans save more for retirement, the Government will also top up the Central Provident Fund Special Accounts or Retirement Accounts of Singaporeans aged 50 and above by $100.  Foreign domestic worker levy has also been further reduced to $200 if the employer or spouse is a Singaporean aged 60 and above.  This lower levy is also available to families with a Singaporean parent, parent-in-law, grandparent or grandparent-in-law aged 65 and above staying in the same household.

 

     Financial measures aside, a comprehensive range of eldercare services is important in enabling the elderly to age in

Column: 423

place.  By tapping on community-based eldercare facilities, such as day care centres, home help and community case management services, the load on the caregivers will be lessened.  My Ministry will continually review and improve eldercare services to meet the needs of the elderly and their families.

 

    The Government is also mindful of the fact that family caregivers carry a heavy load in providing care for their elderly dependants, regardless of financial background, age and marital status.  Many of them have to balance work and family responsibilities, besides providing care for the elderly.  Some may be the sole caregiver for their elderly parents.

 

     Caregivers need our support and attention.  The TOUCH Caregiver Centre provides a one-stop source of information to meet caregiver needs.  In addition to what is available, as mentioned in the Committee of Supply debate, my Ministry will pilot a caregiver support programme.  This provides for 10 care coordinators to be located at eldercare facilities across the island to support family caregivers in their caregiving role.  Also, the Ministry of Manpower has set aside $10 million for initiatives that help companies develop family-friendly practices, including flexible working hours.

 

     Various forms of support schemes and programmes are therefore already in place to help families in their care responsibilities.  Going forward, the Government will continue to monitor and enhance our support for caregivers of elderly members.

 

     Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim (Nominated Member): Sir, I am glad that the Ministry has a range of eldercare support services, schemes and programmes.  However, there are many people and the general public who do not know.  I would like to know whether the Ministry has additional publicity effort to make all these schemes known to the general public.

Column: 424

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  I totally agree with Prof. Ong.  My Ministry will work together with the CDCs, CCCs, grassroots organisations and VWOs to try to disseminate this information.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State whether the Ministry will support a suggestion that exemption be granted, in terms of tax for the maid levy for families also, to single women taking care of aged parents.  Because they also actually need a maid to help them take care of their families.

    Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  Sir, I think singles can take advantage of the lower foreign maid levy available to families which have a Singaporean parent, parent-in-law, grandparent and grandparent-in-law aged 65 years and above staying in the same household.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  Sir, I am aware of that.  What I am asking is about the tax relief.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  Yes, singles can also enjoy the parents' tax relief for the maintenance of one's parents, parents-in-law, grandparents, great grandparents as long as they qualify under the IRAS conditions.  So the tax relief also applies to the singles.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  The Minister has misunderstood my question.  Is the maid levy tax relief applicable to singles?

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  Yes, I mentioned that singles are also entitled. The Government has reduced the maid levy to $200, and as long as the parents, grandparents or great grandparents stay in the same household, whether you are a single or married person, you will get the same entitlement.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  I am talking about the tax relief.  Currently, if a

Column: 425

married woman has a maid, she gets double the maid levy, in terms of the tax relief.  But this is not available to the singles.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  It is only the maid levy, not the tax relief. The tax relief is for them to stay together and they are entitled to that.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  The question is: will the Ministry support the request for tax exemption for singles who are taking care of aged parents and who have a maid?

     Mr Deputy Speaker:  Order.  Mdm Halimah Yacob, can you pose your question and let the Minister of State reply?

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  I mentioned just now that the Ministry will always look into various ways and means to help the families to take care of the elderly.  Because we believe that the family is the first line of support instead of institutional care.  Therefore, I am sure the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Health and my Ministry will always look into ways and means to help.  But at this moment, they are not entitled to that.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  I know they are not entitled to that.  But as the Ministry responsible for looking at all these issues holistically, would it be prepared to make that recommendation to the relevant Ministries to support the same benefit to be extended to single women?

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  As I explained just now, actually the Ministry has carried out a lot of measures to help the family take care of the elderly, like home help, befriender and eldercare daycare centres, neighbourhood link, and so on.  The budget, together with MOH, is about $98 million for financial year 2005 which is an increase of about 4% or 5% every year.  So the Ministry will definitely work

Column: 426

together with the people sector, the families and the communities to do whatever we can.  There is an  inter-ministry committee, which looks into these various ageing issues.  It is chaired by Dr Balaji and my Parliamentary Secretary, Dr Maliki. I am sure they will take all the suggestions into consideration and they will release the report at the end of this year.

Column: 426

STREAMING IN PRIMARY SCHOOL

     2.  Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for Education in view of the strong cultural bias towards students in a certain stream after the streaming in primary school, how will the Ministry make streaming passive so that it does not stress the students and their parents.

     The Minister of State for Education (Mr Chan Soo Sen) (for the Minister for Education):   Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, streaming in schools is a practical approach to help students with different abilities and learning styles so that they can develop as best as they can.  We do this for the best interest of the children. 

 

     There are some students in each cohort who are unable to cope with the regular primary school curriculum, despite the best efforts of the teacher and student.  They benefit from taking a simpler curriculum, which helps them sustain an interest in learning instead of failing repeatedly in their subjects.

 

      Parents whose children are in the EM3 stream, which I presume is what Prof. Ong is referring to, have the choice of putting their children in the regular Primary 5 curriculum as well as EM3. They choose to have their children in the EM3 stream because they believe that it benefits them.

 

      We are introducing greater flexibility into the streaming system where it is practical and educationally beneficial to do

Column: 427

so.   EM3 students who are strong in their mother-tongue can now offer Mother Tongue Language, instead of Basic Mother Tongue Language.  In addition, schools are taking a more flexible approach to see how they can deliver the EM3 curriculum.  EM3 students nowadays join the same class as their peers for specific subjects where there is educational benefit in doing so.  In fact, just a few days ago, I believe that in Zaobao, there was a report of how the two groups of students are working together and enjoying each other's company.   This is similar to the way the schools are banding students in the regular classes according to their strengths and weaknesses in specific subjects.  So I believe issues, like cultural bias, and so on, should not arise with such flexible approaches. 

Column: 427

PROPOSAL TO DEVELOP INTEGRATED RESORTS

     Order read for resumption of debate on Question [18th April 2005],

 

    "That the Proposal to Develop Integrated Resorts be considered by Parliament.". - (Deputy Leader of the House).

 

     Question again proposed.

 

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, many Singaporeans, who feel strongly against the casino, have voiced the view that the IR is a camouflage for the casino.  Like many of these Singaporeans, I too had my initial objections to the idea of a casino in Singapore because of my religious convictions.

 

     I may not have direct experience with the negative impact of gambling.  I grew up observing the bonding effects that mahjong games and "si sek" (the 4-colour cards) have on family members and relatives of a close friend. I remember vividly how my close friend's family look forward to every weekend, where her mother would be doing major cooking and

Column: 428

baking for her children, in-laws, grandchildren and close friends who would gather at her home for mahjong gaming first thing in the morning on weekends.  Whoever was the winner at the end of the day would pay for the food.  There was monetary transaction in all these games, although the stakes were small.

    

     Sir, from this perspective, the game of mahjong was a vehicle in bringing the family members to spend time together.  Nonetheless, if gambling arises out of greed to enrich oneself and the whole mind is consumed by this indulgence then we are in trouble! In one feedback session with professionals, housewives and retirees

who voiced strongly on the social ills of casino gambling, I was awakened by the stories of how gambling has caused so much agony to families.  I can empathise with those who feel strongly against gambling of sorts and I respect their viewpoints.  However, taking a more in-depth approach into the subject matter, I began to develop a better understanding of the rationale for the IR in Singapore.  

 

     Whilst I still have my own personal convictions about the ills of gambling, I have shifted my paradigm to accept the economic rationale for the set up of an IR.  It is not about the casino in the IR.  But in wanting to remake Singapore into a global city, we simply cannot remain as a cultural and economic backwater.  As spoken by many of my parliamentary colleagues, neither do we have a good reason to reject the potential 35,000 jobs that can fill the 35,000 empty stomachs. 

 

     I had an interesting conversation two evenings ago with an old grassroots leader on this recent debate.  This gentleman, who is about 70 years old, grew up in a farm and plantation in old Jurong with his extended two-generation family members.  He told me that the re-making of Singapore and the change that we are going through now is very similar to what he experienced in the early

Column: 429

1960s.  He related the strong kampong opposition in old Jurong in the early 60s when the Government started its re-settlement programme to re-house kampong dwellers to high-rise flats.  These farmers felt dislodged from the comforts of their kampong life and resented being pigeon-holed in the high-rise public housing.  There were outcries that big families were being separated by this resettlement programme which would lead to erosion of extended family ties, "gotong-royong" spirit and, instead, nurturing of self-centredness and selfishness because the family nucleus was now much smaller and the pigeon-holed dwelling encouraged each to keep to his own.

 

     There was also a need to retrain themselves for other vocations as they could no longer do farming.  Other laments included the ills of living in high-rise flats as they provided convenient suicide platforms for people to jump down.  This reminds me of a remark my parliamentary colleague Gan Kim Yong made to me during the recent Budget debate.  He asked me how I would feel and face the family members whose breadwinner had jumped down due to gambling debts and also if this family happened to be my constituents.  Extending Gan Kim Yong's question further, this question should also be posed to the decision-makers who made the decision to build high-rise flats in the 60s in Singapore.  In this analogy, high-rise flats have made it easy for suicidal individuals to end their life!  Sir, there will be no end as to who is to be blamed for one's final fate. 

 

     The casino debate is also being debated among my three children.  My 12-year-old daughter, in her pure innocence, uttered, "So bad!  How can we allow for gambling in Singapore?"  Her two elder brothers responded, "There may

Column: 430

be gambling in Singapore but you are in control of yourself and you have a choice not to join in."

 

     Sir, all indulgences can lead to positive or negative outcomes, depending on our purposes and on how we balance ourselves at the end of the day.  This requires self-responsibility and discipline which we owe to ourselves to cultivate.  The story that my grassroots leader related is very similar to the transition that we are going through today with the decision to go ahead with the IR.  In the early days, it was resettlement that caused uprooting of livelihood, followed by industrialisation, that led to outcries against pollution.  Singapore then had to remake itself in order to survive.  The outcry todate is that we should remove all undesirable activities from our people and insulate them.   Just like in the 60s, Singaporeans were not too sure then, whether we would make it, in the remaking.  But we did. 

 

     Sir,  Singapore has proven time and time again that it can survive against the odds.  Surely we cannot be saying that the social and moral fabric of our nation is so flimsy that the introduction of the IRs is going to cause it to disintegrate.  I think not.  We are made of stronger stuff.  It can be a heart-rending decision for many religious individuals when it comes to having to make a choice on matters of the secular world.  But we have to look at the big picture and take a discerning and practical step to do what is best for the future viability of our country.  The fundamental point really is for us to be able to continue to upkeep our moral values and exercise self-responsibility and vigilance.  Yet at the same time, we must be realistic and understand the need to do what is right for the viability of the country.  We will continue to have problems, but we must seek and evolve solutions on our own over time. 

 

     Opposition MP Chiam See Tong has said that once we officially plant the seed

Column: 431

of gambling in our soil, it is a question of time that it will grow and spread in our land.  My rejoinder is that unless we neglect the regular pruning, our growers will ensure that these plants will be properly cropped and contained and will be the pride of our garden. I am sure that the IR will have to evolve to an icon that we can be proud of. 

 

     Often, I meet people and when I tell them that I am from Singapore, they say, "Oh, yes, Singapore, nice airport."  Because they do not get beyond Changi Airport.  Too often, Singapore is seen as a 24-hour stopover enroute to other cities.  We need to change that.  We need to cultivate, as the Prime Minister referred to, the X factor.  But we also need to cultivate the "wow factor" and the "zap factor".  In fact, convention organisers have been lamenting that they often are at a blank as to what else to offer to the top-notch business leaders visiting Singapore.  We do not just need to remake Singapore; we need a complete makeover for Singapore!  At these crossroads, we have to look for new engines of growth for the economy.  Whilst China is now becoming the "factory of the world" and India, the "world's back office", Singapore should remake itself into a global service entertainment hub.  

 

     I am of the view that the IRs will not make gambling any more or less prevalent, provided proper regulations and safeguards are put in place.  I am comforted by the announcements by MCYS, MHA and MOH of the frameworks that will be put in place to mitigate the social ills and possible abuses that will be posed by the IRs.

 

     Drawing on research from overseas, experience shows that legalising casinos can actually minimise gambling-related problems, because the methods for controlling and treating gambling addictions are developed and well enforced.  Often, gambling related problems arise in

Column: 432

societies where gambling is prohibited because it is only too easy to assume that the problem does not exist.  What is important is that we have to continuously ensure that the industry will be transparent and strictly regulated by the Government.  The IRs will be a clean and well-run business.  Singapore's strong governance will ensure that any IR is run like a corporation, hence minimising potential social ills.  Also, with our infrastructure and fine-tuned regulatory system, we are likely to attract tenders from only the most professional of IR operations.

 

     One question that arises is how will the Government balance the interests of investors with those of the public. Other countries, including US and Australia, have gaming commissions to regulate the gaming industry.  They also have the power to impose penalties if the casino contravenes those regulations.  Have we given sufficient thought as to how we will impose and enforce similar controls in Singapore?  As hon. Member Mr Tan Soo Khoon observed, the $100 levy may not be sufficient to deter the hardened gamblers.  This is why I think we need to distinguish between two categories of casino users.  

 

     Firstly, those people who have the occasional flutter but could otherwise conceivably develop an addiction and, secondly, the hardened gamblers.  As far as the latter is concerned, disincentives are not necessarily going to wean them away from their addiction.  But, then again, nor is the presence or the absence of a casino in Singapore.  We need to have in place different strategies to deal with each of these types of casino users.

 

     The revenue from the levies and other forms of funds that may be invested to develop the  national framework for public education, as well as to help with gambling addicts, must be put to good use.  What NMP Mr Steve Chia has

Column: 433

suggested with regard to supporting the families of the gambling addicts is a sure way of breeding more gambling addicts.  Sir, we must ensure that these monies would not be utilised to support a crutch mentality amongst the indulgents and cause them to be irresponsible to their family members.  Whilst we need to provide support to the family members of  gambling addicts, we must never end up dishing easy money or else it would only fuel their irresponsibility towards their family members.  The monies would be better utilised for public education on the ills of gambling and for establishing safeguards for monitoring and auditing of operational practices and processes so as to ensure that we close all the loopholes.  

 

     At this point, I would also like to ask the Government whether there has been any survey carried out to determine the average amount spent per person on legalised bets, jackpot machines, Big Sweep, Toto, 4-D and football bets.  It is important that we develop and maintain key economic and social statistics so as to monitor the economic benefits and social costs of gambling in Singapore.  This will enable us to better address our future strategies in managing the IR industry. 

 

     Sir, the IR would be a boost to job creation and our GDP.  Indeed, there will be many types of primary jobs that would be created by the development of the IRs.  These jobs will range from security guards and croupiers to executives and managers and other professionals.  The spin-off jobs would likely be generated in the SMEs because of the economic multiplier effect.  This is largely because IRs source many of their services from SME firms. 

 

     An issue that has been raised by many Singaporeans is whether there will be sufficient high-end jobs for Singaporeans.  Sir, the high-end jobs are likely to be filled by foreigners in view of the fact that

Column: 434

Singapore lacks expertise within the areas of IR and gaming management.  However, these skills are transferable and should be taught to Singaporeans sooner.  Will the Singapore Government be setting any timeline for these skills to be transferred to Singaporeans?  It is important that the selected IR operators will partner the Singapore Government and other training providers in Singapore to train Singaporeans for these jobs.  In this, Sentosa Tourism Academy should reach out to the training providers in Singapore and provide the "Train-a-Trainer" kits, so that we will at the same time ensure that there will be sufficient well-equipped and competent training providers in Singapore to train service providers in people skills and managing human resources skills for this sector.  I can envisage a vibrant training industry in this sector evolving.

 

     Sir, at the same time, we must also face the challenge of changing the paradigm of Singaporeans with respect to employment within the IR and casino, especially among those who strongly object to the casino.  Here, mindset training is crucial, and we should tap on the established training providers on mindset training to partner Sentosa Training Academy on this aspect of training.  My worry is that we can bring the horse to the water, but the horse may not drink it and, if this were so, from structural unemployment, we may now be faced with "mindset unemployment" arising from religious and moral objections to working in the IRs with casinos. 

 

     In the light of the thousands of jobs that will be created, either directly or indirectly, the issue, as far as many Singaporeans are concerned, is how many unemployed Singaporeans, including retirees, would be able to find employment in this industry.  I hope that, at some point, more information will be shared on how the unemployed, including retirees, can be retrained for some of the jobs in the IRs.  One segment of the retail line that would be suitable for retirees

Column: 435

would be souvenir shops in the IRs.  I propose that a task force be formed to explore further how we can engage retirees who are still strong and healthy for vocations in the retail line in the IRs. 

 

     In conclusion, Sir, the debate on the casino in the IRs over these last few months has provided Singapore with a mirror to reflect on what it must do in going forward.  It is just like an ageing individual or, if you like, a maturing individual looking into the mirror and realising, "I am not looking fresh and attractive anymore."  Here, these two individuals have two choices. 

 

     One is to let it be and age graciously and fade away.  I remember my maternal grandmother who, according to my mother, started to don black trousers and blue samfoo and bundled her hair when she turned 40, because that was the right thing to do for somebody who was brought up in a very closed and traditional family.  When she was 70, she would tell her visitors that she was waiting to die, even though she was in the pink of health.  Finally, she died at the age of 90.  She was an old grand lady who refused to change with time, and took pride in that.  And for a good 50 years, she bowed prematurely to the twilight years of life and without much excitement. 

 

     The second choice is to change the hairstyle, colour the lips and cheeks a little bit, so that the individual continues to look fresh and re-energised and send a signal that life is still young and exciting.  But that does not mean that we have loose moral values.  Sir, the point is that being seasoned does not mean becoming obsolete.  Being seasoned can mean growing and venturing.  Author T S Eliot said, "Old man [and I qualify, it includes women too] ought to be explorers." 

 

     Sir, in going forward, Singapore should have a blast in remaking itself.  At the grassroots level, it is such a paradigm

Column: 436

shift that has made line dancing so popular amongst the senior citizens in community centres today and has given the senior citizens a rejuvenation of not only their hopes and their dreams, but their physical and mental well-being.  Surely, Sir, Singapore must choose the second choice. 

 

     On this note, I urge that we move on and give our

support to the Prime Minister who will have to shoulder this responsibility of remaking Singapore with a blast in having two IRs. 

     Miss Penny Low (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the casino debate has been a very difficult issue that has given me much grey hair. 

 

      To be or not to be, that is the question. To put the issue upfront, I am not for gambling.  I know of enough gamblers that put their families through turmoils to convince that gambling traps those who cannot discipline themselves and traps their families and friends along with their habit as well.  And for the pathological gamblers, it is all of the bad and none of the good.

 

      In my entire life, I think I gambled four times.  One was betting on a 4-D out of good fun at a retreat. The number came out but in reverse order.  I lost $2. Another was in Las Vegas while I waited for a group of friends who had been delayed last minute.  I have been to Las Vegas and casinos many times but never gambled.  I have observed casino operations and the punters throughout these visits, but never quite felt the urge to punt.  But that time, as I had time to kill, I decided to change US$5 into coins for the one-arm bandits (jackpot machines) just to understand what sets punters' hearts racing and also to keep myself occupied.

 

      I was on the nickel machines, winning about five cents.  I kept winning, and losing and winning again.  After about

Column: 437

half an hour, I still had money left.  Much as I tried, it was not easy to get rid of the US$5 on the nickel machines.  It was a little bit boring for me.  I got tired and gave up with a nickel and dimes left from the US$5.

 

     The third and fourth time was at the Turf Club during charity races.  I was invited in my capacity as Treasurer of the Equestrian Federation of Singapore and at both charity races, President Nathan was the Guest-of-Honour.  Betting on horse races was new to me and it was quite complicated.  But as it was a charity race and everyone placed their bets, I did so too.  During the first charity event, I bet on two races out of 10.  I won one, lost the other, it was a net gain.  During the second charity event, I understood the game a little better and I bet on four out of 10 of the races.  Lady luck was smiling at me and miraculously,  I actually won all four bets and collected quite  a tidy sum, not bad at all.

 

      But does that make me want to try again?  It is a firm "no".  Sir, I guess different folks, different strokes.  While travelling off the beaten path, hitch-hiking, water sports and perhaps even extreme sports may set my adrenalin rushing, I felt nothing more than a smile at those wins.  Of course, I bet small.  I am also a timid gambler. I never believe in easy money nor gambling to wealth.  There may be short-term wins, but I have never met a gambler who wins in the long term.  Even in the movies like "qian wang zhi wang", "du shen", God of Gamblers or the Godfather, the protagonists never really wins, but suffered great tragedies instead.  I believe in hard work and thrift and hence, whether the casino is on-shore or off-shore, whether I am in a casino or out of a casino, it makes no difference to my basic value system and make-up.  I believe that there are many people like me who will not be negatively influenced by the existence of casinos.

 

Column: 438

     Then there is also another group who will gamble anyway, if not here, in Batam, Genting, Macau, Las Vegas and somewhere in the cruise to nowhere.  In fact, very soon, they will also be gambling in the virtual cyber-world. We need to help this group better manage themselves.

 

    But the group that I am really concerned with is the in-between who may be attracted by the glitz and greed in the casino, who walk into a casino by chance and get hooked by the casino operator's design. Sir, nobody goes to a casino, expecting to lose money, but they end up losing.  Most people only wanted to try their luck once or twice but they could not leave thereafter.  This is, in fact, how Chia Teck Leng got hooked.  Let me quote Chia:

 

    "I started gambling in casinos in 1994.  It started innocuously enough.  I was simply passing time on board a cruise ship on a lazy afternoon.  By pure chance, I had walked into its only casino, to be accosted by alluring colourful lights, attractive croupiers and the magical promise of easy money€¦  Just when I was wallowing in the glamour and triumph of my new found wealth, tragedy struck.  I completely lost my footing.  I made a goodbye tape in the event.  At the point when I was arrested, I was purportedly the second biggest casino gambler in the world."

 

As we know, he cheated banks of $117 million and has been sentenced behind bars for 42 years. 

 

     I am sure that we will never endeavour a Singaporean to be the number one gambler in the world.  The question is:  how many Chia Teck Lengs will there be and how many mini-Chias can our society handle?  If the gambling problem can be confined to himself or herself, then the problem is containable. The truth is that for every gambler, there is at least one family and a social network that is negatively affected.

 

    According to the MCYS' survey, this may be translated to 2.1% or 55,000

Column: 439

gamblers.  In other words, even without the casino, we have at least 55,000 affected families or at least 200,000 people or so negatively affected by the gambling ills. This is no small problem.  What more with the casino next door operating 24/7 round the clock?  Sir, one family affected is one family too many.  There is cost on both the social front and the economic front that cannot be ignored.

 

    Last Monday, a 60-year-old resident came to my MPS for the 19th time.  Her plea:  early withdrawal of her remaining CPF.  Her reason:  her son had borrowed from the loan sharks and has gone mad from the pressure.  He is now, in fact,  at the Institute of Mental Health.  She is left to carry the burden of repayment and she sobs each time she comes.  But over the 19 times that I hear her, I realised that much of the money owed were gambling debts - hers and her son's.  Chances are that she is probably still at it.

 

     I shiver to think what might happen to her and many others come 2009.  More will come to ask for early withdrawal of CPF.  More 55-year-olds who just withdraw their CPF money may also be found at the gambling tables and jackpot machines. This is worrisome as we already face a looming retirement funding issue. Yet, in every MPS, there are people who come to seek help to defer payment of arrears and ask for jobs.  In fact, they make up the majority.  For every gambling case, there are at least 15-20 cases of job-seekers and payment problems.  With no job and many bills to pay, families face hardship and can be a social problem. That is the reality and the dilemma that we face.

 

     Sir, when the debate first started, it looks like a case of economic value versus social values and appears to be a case of which value is more important to us as a society.  Frankly, I would rather have a first-class society and live a simpler life

Column: 440

than a first-class economy with third class society.

 

    Those who are against asked:   what price economic development?  Those who are pro said that gambling is already prevalent and we need to bring back some lost revenue and create more economic avenues at the same time.  So who is right or wrong?  Through this, no one is right or wrong.  It is a judgement call which verdict can only be known in retrospect. What is certain, however, is that this is no easy or hasty decision but one that has been deliberated and decided on by tough minds and warm hearts, all working towards ensuring jobs for Singaporeans and a better living.

 

     Obviously, without a robust economy and a face lift for the landscape of Singapore, many businesses would scout around the region for a lower cost hub that also boasts of good infrastructure and city buzz.

 

     A robust economy and jobs for everyone is critical to Singapore's survival. We have positioned ourselves well in the region and international arena. But we are past the era of a sleepy neighbourhood.  In fact, our nearest neighbours are already giving us a run for our money, as India and the China dragon awaken at the same time. 

 

     In the last two years, I met many young and successful entrepreneurs from the region who are part of the network called "The New Asian Leaders". They are all under 40 years old and run successful multi-million businesses. When asked if they have been to Singapore, they said "yes".  When asked if they would think of expanding to Singapore, the majority said no.  Singapore is not on their radar screen, whether for market size reasons, cost factors or competitive reasons.  It got me worried.

 

     For a long time, we are a preferred destination.  But for this group who will

Column: 441

continue to grow and will become important movers and shakers in the new economy, Singapore is not on their radar screen.  I think we need to seriously remake ourselves economically in order to keep our economy humming and bring jobs to the people. The IRs will bring a potential 35,000 jobs and indeed, like Mr Lim Boon Heng said, it is a number that is difficult to ignore.

 

     As the debate progresses, I realise that there is more to the argument of economics versus social benefits equation that meets the eye.  It is not just about which value we treasure more.  It is about the tone that we want to set for the Singapore society at large.  The tone we want to set for our society is in fact the issue that I grapple with a lot. 

 

     For decades, we have said no to casino because we do not want to change the ethos and values in our society, which is honest living through thrift and hard work.  We wanted to protect our citizens from the negative influences of vices like organised crimes and gambling which erode our ethos.  We make sure that they do not enter our shores.  Hence, saying "no" to casino was a no-brainer.

 

    Yet, on 18th April 2005, we relented and said "yes".  Is it because this generation of leaders have met with unprecedented challenges and gone soft?  Are we seeking the easy way out?  Is the decision to reap easy profit based on pure economic reasons alone?  Or is this what the majority of our people want?  But are our people mature enough to decide on such issues which circumstances and information may not be available to them? 

 

    In retrospect, this is the critical point for the decision-making. And this is a critical difference between 40 years ago and now.  Some 40-50 years ago, information was scarce and so was overseas

Column: 442

travel. Anything which was not on-shore almost had little or no influence on the lives and paradigms of our people.  Then, people needed to focus on basic bread-and-butter and all that they know would have a high correlation of what the Government wanted them to know.

 

     Today, the equation is different. There are cable TV, Internet and, of course, the frequent travels that expose Singaporeans to different people, lifestyles, priorities and viewpoints. The Government no longer has a monopoly on his mindset.  If a desired lifestyle cannot be found here, many are educated enough and in sufficient demand in the region or the world to uproot and move with their feet.

 

     In that sense, we must offer sufficient space for the individuals to dream their dreams and live the lives that they so desire. Indeed, Singapore and her people have matured well, especially in the last few years. The very challenging circumstances like the discovery of the Jemaah Islamiyah terrorist cell groups in Singapore, the once fiery water and cross-straits issues, SARS, bird flu and, more recently, our reaction to the tsunami disaster, all demonstrate a good degree of resilience and maturing of our society at large. 

 

     Collectively, we have proven to be a cool-headed people with a community spirit with a good sense of emergency and positive action to match. We are, after all, 40 years old and it is time to trust our people, have confidence in our people and let them decide.  So I set out, at every occasion, when I meet with my residents and grassroots leaders, asking them for their opinion, conducting straw polls on the casino issue. The latest was done on Sunday, 17th April, 

and there was an overwhelming number of pro-IR residents.  Of course, this is also borne out by the recent newspaper articles.  The question is:  can they take care of themselves and be disciplined?  I think certainly not all

Column: 443

can.  But is this what they want?  For the majority, yes.  Well, then I say, "The ayes have it, the ayes have it."

 

     The IR sets a new tone for society.  It is a tone that is more open, one where we trust our people to make the decision for themselves and, therefore, one that expects also responsibility from the people as more choices are put in front of them.

 

     Moving on now to some practical concerns.  Sir, the proposals from the two IRs come from world-class players.  These are mega gaming boys with international network and clients from all walks of life.  Within every IR, there is also a complex eco-system of casino operators, junkets, sharks and thugs, and an unseen financial system that oils the machinery.  To tighten the reins and choke the engine may bring an early end to the ventures.  To allow the eco-system to grow would negatively impact our ethos.  It will not be an easy balance or, even possible, to keep out the bad altogether.  World-class IRs will attract world-class organised crimes which are sophisticated.  The question is:  do you have sufficient tools to deal with them?  How far would we go in dealing with them?  I would appreciate further clarification on our defence mechanism.

 

     On the other safeguards to be introduced, my sense is that casino operators would also come out with counter-measures to beat them.  These are big players with extensive experience in human psychology in attracting punters.  In fact, they hire Ivy League professors to design game floor and lure curious onlookers. 

 

     Let me give some examples.  First, the slot machines, and this goes back to my second experience at gambling at the slot machine with the US$5.  It was not that I was lucky that I kept winning, but rather because these are five-cent machines and I was the free labour.  How does it work? 

Column: 444

Basically, the casinos are designed in such a way that they will try to generate as much noise and buzz, as possible, to passers-by.  So, at the fringe of it would be the cheap slot machines - one cent, five cents, and so on.  The idea is not for them to lose their money, but for them to create all the ringing sound of money dropping from the slot machines.  Then as one progresses inwards, towards the core of the casino, there would then be the 25-cents, the 50-cents, $1, $10 and, of course, ultimately at the core would be the gambling tables.  That is the psychology.

 

     Another example.  A particular casino operator has come out with a card called the "winner's card".  In this winner's card, what they do is to track the identity of the punter with the life-time economic value calculated.  Whenever the punter comes to the casino and puts it into the slot machine or their own booth, it would send information through the central computer system to tell and track the winnings or losses of the punter.  If they found that the punter is losing quite a bit of money, someone would turn up out of the blue and ask, "Sir or Madam, are you having a good game?  Would you like some free vouchers for the theatres, hotels or F&B?"  Therefore, the guy goes back happy losing, not knowing that his economic life value is being tracked there.

 

     There are many such examples, but I would like to move on to also voice another concern I have.  I am especially concerned about the notion of normalising gambling, especially amongst children.  In recent years, children are getting into the betting scenarios, especially with soccer betting.  But that is once in four years, or when the World Cup happens.  But, maybe they are doing it more now.  And with the casino would we further normalise it?  I am not sure.  But I think what we must do is to strengthen the core values and basic family units that our society stands for and, in fact, to also

Column: 445

strengthen our financial planning principles so that we can be very clear what can be gambled away and what cannot be put on the betting table.

 

     Sir, in all, I think our people have spoken and so did the Cabinet.  I reckon that, to be or not to be, was the question.  Now that the decision has been made, we need to put our bets on Prime Minister Lee, who has unequivocally assumed the ultimate responsibility of the decision and win big.  Be in the winner's circle as a united people.  We need to rally behind the decision and make it a success.  While PM bears the ultimate responsibility, people must share in the responsibility to make Singapore a success.  After all, as the Chinese saying goes, "guo jia xing wang, pi fu you ze". 

 

     A successful IR will certainly reap economic benefits which may be re-channelled to treat social ills and promote community strength, while a failed IR would leave us with all the social ills and negative economic equity.  We have to get past this stage and focus on the objectives of this landmark decision, which is to transform not just the facade of Singapore, but also the core of Singapore, to inject life, responsibility, self and mutual help of the individual and the community.  All eyes are on the IR now and I certainly hope that the IR or the casino will not become the only icon of Singapore.  I think we need to complete the painting of our economic and social landscape on the canvas.  We need a fuller picture of where we are going tomorrow.  May I call on the people to support the Cabinet's decision so that we may move forward together and also on the Cabinet to complete the painting of Singapore's social, physical and economic landscape on the canvas so that our people can track the same path with the Cabinet as one united people. 

Column: 446

     Mr Andy Gan Lai Chiang (Marine Parade): Sir, after viewing the various proposals submitted by well-known resort operators for the proposed integrated resort at Marina Bayfront and Sentosa, I was impressed by the confidence that investors have in our country, and it made me see the economic benefits that could radiate from this massive project from a different perspective.  I have begun to view this project not as a dedicated gaming house but a sight that may position Singapore as a country that has the influence and capacity to reach out to the rest of the world, notwithstanding its limited land size.  Before viewing this, I had a very sceptical impression of such a resort, built upon my impression of how Las Vegas casinos started off, and how it subsequently took on a disguised image of a family-destination successfully drawing in the crowds despite being located in desert country.

 

     Personally, I am not in favour of promoting the setting up of a casino in Singapore, in spite of it occupying a small area in the proposed integrated resort, as the ill effects of a casino, apart from the evils of gambling, are well-known.  Furthermore, a casino gives a sleazy image to a country that has built its foundation on hard work and with a clean, honest and efficient Government leading it.  Many of my colleagues in this House have given examples of how bad the effects of gambling have on people, and I agree with them.  We should then try to reach out to as many as possible and inform them not to be lured by the hope of winning big in gambling.  The social ills of casino have a tendency of passing through the walls that are supposed to trap the on-goings of casinos within and, if not carefully managed, will creep into the social fabric of our nation, changing the good values cultivated over the years and which has helped bind our different communities together. 

 

     The danger of casinos causing a subculture to develop and controlling the

Column: 447

behaviour and thinking of the people and advocating all that the casino offers are something which Singapore as a small country will have to be aware of.  As we live in a compact society, it would be difficult for one not to influence the other and, subsequently, collectively let our guards down to the ill effects of such an industry. 

 

    As we cannot live in a glass bubble, we must then guard ourselves against undesirable values of the casino which are not conducive to good social values.  However, as I have stated earlier, other aspects of the IR cannot be ignored and will need to be recognised especially for its economic values.  It has the potential to attract the rest of the world to us and to bring Singapore to the level of other major cities of the world.  It has been demonstrated that the operators of the IR has the range of soft capabilities to draw on visitors to Singapore, allowing the latest attraction in entertainment, be it music, film or concerts and other conferences to be staged here.  Such a magnetic pull will be important to Singapore as many other countries in the region are also trying to be such a place. 

 

     I support the Prime Minister's decision in having the IR for Singapore, as it would create not only more jobs in a big way, but also lift the level of excitement in business circles and introduce new activities for families to enjoy, as in the theme parks.  All these and world-class events have been missing since our early history.  However, I will, on the other hand, not support any decision to allow the proliferation of casinos beyond what has been committed.  We have to be sensitive to the feelings of those who are opposed to gambling, and the Government must gauge the sentiment of the people very carefully, especially when the country is moving towards a more open society.  I know it must have been a most difficult decision for the Prime Minister to make to allow the IR to house the casino. 

Column: 448

But now that the decision has been made, we must all rally around him and make a success of the IR.  The care and intensity that the Government has placed on this subject has shown that it will deal with the future social problems arising from gambling with great concern.

 

     From my discussion with my grassroots leaders on the casino issue, I have the impression that many do not have the correct knowledge of what an IR is made up of.  Some still have the impression that the IR looks like a big casino building.  Others see it as a row of huge hotel buildings fronting the waterfront, imposing itself on other smaller buildings currently standing in the vicinity of the proposed sites, especially the Sentosa site.  Their thoughts are not far from how casinos and resorts look like compared to the images that they have seen over TV and in the papers, who in turn have used pictures of other casinos and resorts in their reports.  In contrast, the IR concepts that I have seen are not only futuristic in design, but also conjure a sense of confidence.  Surprisingly, it also blends well with the surrounding landscape with hardly any images of a casino on the exterior.  So, I would like to urge the Government to consider revealing as soon as possible some images of what the two IRs will, or may look like, so that the casino's images do not get entrenched itself in the public's mind.  This will then help the public to concentrate on the positive effects of what the IRs can bring.

 

     If an IR with a casino is the way to go for Singapore to succeed in competing with the rest of the countries in the region, then we must be prepared to live with the ill effects that it will bring.  The lure of big monies through games of chance and its social problems will surely permeate into the population.  Thus, new measures must be in place to curb as far as possible all ill effects of the casino.  Our legal system and police force must be equipped with the powers to prevent

Column: 449

related crimes and money laundering from spreading.  The local residents must be shielded from the lure of bright lights of the gaming halls

and entry barriers reviewed regularly to restrict the tempting urge to enter the gates of the casino.  Our religious and community groups must improve their moral teaching methods to instil good values to the young and old, so that they will be able to withstand the temptations before them and be able to make the right choices for themselves.

 

     Sir, allow me to digress slightly from the problems of gambling to an observation on transport matters that I feel may cause some irritation to visitors and locals patronising the future IRs.  As the two IRs will be located in the south of Singapore and within a few minutes' drive of each other, road congestion will surely be the order of the day.  Already the Marina South highway and the roads leading to Sentosa are seeing traffic jams now and then.  What more will we see when the two IRs come up?  I hope the Ministry of Transport will make a thorough study of the networks of roads leading to the IRs as the volume of traffic will surely increase on a daily basis and will be worse when functions and conventions are being hosted.

 

     Similarly, healthcare cases of pathological gamblers will also increase.  Every day, we are faced with addictions in many forms, such as drug addiction and other immoral addictions.  Gambling addiction will add to the increase in the number of addicts. Here, I am assured by the Minister for Health that the Health Ministry will be prepared to handle increased problems in this area.  Research will have to be updated and immediate action put in place which, unfortunately, will lead to an increase in healthcare expenditure.

 

    Sir, our nation has to move on with the times to be economically successful.  At

Column: 450

the same time, we are subjected to all sorts of new temptations daily, sometimes moving us to do things which are against our best moral judgement.  We must be prepared as a society to find ways to keep our social values deeply rooted so that come what may, we are still the best country to live in.  The different races living together and working together can continue to do so as long as we keep our work ethics intact and the belief that economic success comes from hard work and strong family values. 

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, for the past few days, we have listened to many different voices.  I feel that the Government's decision to allow the opening of IRs with casinos is a very important one.  I look at this problem in a wider perspective.  If we do not have Minister George Yeo's suggestion, we may not have that durian in place today, and we may not have this debate today.  I would like to thank him for his two durians and also for this platform to debate on the matter of casino in Singapore.
 

     We have to respect the different voices to prevent and stop extreme gambling.  First, we must admit that it is a fact that not everybody would have the same opinion and the same voice.  Among Singaporeans, there are some who are staunchly against the setting up of casinos.  We respect their opinions and we actually listen to their voices.  Because we have these pillars in these fast-moving streams, they help us to hold to our value system in our society.   

 

     Now, let us listen to different voices and also the different opinions about the IRs.  You may have heard about them in the past few days.  I think it is worth the while listening to them again.  Of course, there is no right or wrong in these opinions.  There are some people who actually feel it is all right to gamble on football but object to IRs because of the casino component.  Some go to the turf

Column: 451

club for horse betting but they are staunchly against the casino.  There is a Japanese businessman who told me that in a golf course you can actually lose or win thousands of dollars but the golfers still do not support the opening of casinos.  Some people worry that our reputation of an honest, clean, serious, hardworking attitude and value system will collapse and we will have a society filled with all types of undesirable people and things. Of course, there are those who worry about the social problems that may be brought about by the opening of the casino with the rise in drug-trafficking, prostitution, loan sharks and organised crimes.  Some are afraid that Singaporeans may become compulsive gamblers and the percentage will increase from the present 2.1% and jump manifold.  Thus, the society has to pay much more for this.

 

     A very close friend of mine told me that she opposed the establishment of integrated resorts with casinos. She feels that everybody is drunk, and she is the only one who is sober.  I am not sure if I am one of those who are drunk or I am sober.  Of course, there are many people who presume or do not really know that a lot of Singaporeans are already gambling.  Some people agree to the IR but are against the casino.  Some people doubt if this will really bring about good and new jobs for our people. Some people actually oppose it because of their religion or political standpoints.  At the same time, we also hear another voice - a very loud voice.

     A few days ago, a colleague in Parliament told me that his women's group fully supports this and they want the Government to set this up as soon as possible.  This is because a lot of Singaporeans already go to cruise ships or overseas to gamble.  So, there is a huge amount of money flowing out of Singapore.  Rather than letting the money flow out, why do we not just let the money remain in Singapore? 


Column: 452

     Of course, there are people who cannot wait for this project to be completed, so that they do not have to take a boat or bus to Batam or Macau, etc, to gamble.  And there are some business people who hope that this project will bring about more opportunities that will boost the tourism services or the property sector.

     Some foreign businessmen also told me that they felt that this is a new way to let Singapore  reinvent itself.  However, there are also some intellectuals who feel that a little gambling is good for the temperament.  And this is perhaps why the Chinese people like to gamble.  MCYS actually pointed out that a lot of people feel that gambling is a social activity.  To them, to have this IR with a casino is just one more place for them to spend their leisure time.  There is another voice, which is also a very loud voice, that a little gambling is a way to buy hope.  There is another group of people who feel that gambling can make them rich, and these are the people who are most likely to become gambling addicts.  However, there are some who say that when they were studying overseas, they have seen students gambling away their tuition fees.  But a lot of them actually still work hard and come back with a degree.  They have seen all types of IRs with casinos and are well exposed.  So they do not think that this is a big problem.

 

     There are others who feel that Singapore has already developed into a mature society, and Singaporeans can think independently and they do not need the Government to "mother" them around.  So, they feel that they have to be responsible for their own activities.  Others feel that this could be a project that will bring about new job opportunities for the older and low-skilled Singaporeans.  For this, I personally feel that this project could bring us new jobs but we have to retrain our workers, particularly the older workers, so that they can take on these new jobs. I have come across many older

Column: 453

workers who try very hard to learn how to operate new machines to clean the floor.  It seems that there is no other way.  For these older and low-skilled people, I feel that it is a very good opportunity.  Some people feel that this could bring about more tax income for Singapore.  This is what I hear from our vice-chairperson.  For this increase in tax income, it can actually help to tackle the aging problem where health is concerned.

 

      From these supporting or opposing voices, we have to weigh the positive and the negative effects, and make a good decision, to see which decision will impact our economy and our people in the long run.  We have to look at the problem positively.  We have to use education through the masses to ensure that our society will be protected, and through legal ways to lower the impact that it could bring. 

 

     This debate serves to educate not only the future gamblers but also the present gamblers and the people of Singapore in general. My Ministry will start this educational process as soon as possible. We are not going to wait until the casino is set up before we start educating Singaporeans.  We are going to start now.  The Government will use all its resources through multi-Ministerial cooperation and strategies to help prevent and halt excessive gambling. This should be done through the three Ministries - Home Affairs, MCYS and Health - to set up a safety net to make sure that Singaporeans will not be lured into pathological gambling and give rise to family and social problems. Of course, we cannot totally avoid all these problems.  Our well-known so-called "Home Team" led by Minister Wong Kan Seng can curb the problem of loan sharks.

     We have to transmit the right values to our people through our education system, the media, the religious

Column: 454

organisations and the VWOs.  These will include honesty, hard work and other values. The confession of Mr Chia Teck Leng, who is serving his prison sentence for fraud resulting from compulsive gambling, is a very good material for public education.

     Some people think that Singapore is a piece of clean land.  If we build a casino, it will increase gambling many times.  But, of course, we have to realise that gambling has been in Singapore all along.  If we look at the MCYS' report, where gambling is concerned, Singapore is not losing out to Hong Kong or Macau.  Singaporeans buy Toto, 4-D, gamble on football, and many even put their bets with illegal operators. They go to Batam and Genting.  If you look at Jack Neo's movie, Tu Ran Fa Cai, ie, getting rich suddenly, you can see that during the weekends in the void decks, there are a lot of people gambling. So if you want to help these people, we have to choose a bigger way. A lot of people gamble and they do it socially.  Only 2.1% have a problem.  And, of course, what we are concerned with is especially this group of people.  We know that most Singaporeans are mature and they know how to look after themselves, and are responsible to their family and society.  The person who is in charge of Cosner also points out that in America, as long as you actually keep a cap on gambling, we can avoid excessive gambling.  In fact, if you look at all those gamblers, they are not that many. Of course, we have to have the risk-taking attitude to cultivate good entrepreneurial spirit.  This is good for them, good for the country and it helps to start their own businesses.


     In setting up the IR with casino, is it going to make Singapore a third-class city?  Let us look at Melbourne in Australia.  Since 1861, every year in November, they have the Melbourne Cup.  It is just like a carnival.  There are men and women who dress themselves up and

Column: 455

they wear beautiful hats.  They have a price for the best dressed person, etc.  If you look at this horse betting, it is not the focal point, but a place or occasion for the whole family to have a carnival.  Last year, I went to Vancouver. Along the two hours' journey from Vancouver to Seattle, there are six different casinos.  If you look at these two cities, Melbourne and Vancouver, they are among the best choice cities to live in the whole world. They are ranked among the first few choice cities in the world.  Another place is Monaco. It is a country which is smaller than Singapore and it has the very well known Monte Carlo casino.  

 

     Whether Singapore will degenerate into a third class society will depend on whether the Government knows how to regulate the operation of the casino and pull the stops whenever necessary.  In the 80s, when I was in the NTUC, we had the same problem of whether or not we should have the jackpot machines at our NTUC Club. If not for these jackpot machines, we would have closed down long ago.  Of course, we had to have a lot of money to set up all the different activities.  At that time, the late Mr Ong Teng Cheong advised us to understand why these people gamble.  Most of these workers who go to the Club gamble only on small amounts.  He said, "Well, if they want to gamble, why don't we let them gamble the money here?"  So we can use this money to have other activities like sponsoring an orchestra to perform at various venues and raise funds for the various activities. 

 

     These jackpot machines actually bring in the funds we need. Mr Ong Teng Cheong said that we must make sure that those people who sat there playing the jackpot machines for too long, we must ask them to go home.  We must not make gambling become too excessive.  If we compare this to the NTUC Clubs, this is quite similar.  The strategy is similar.  If we want to have large-scale international activities or cultural activities, and we do

Column: 456

not have the money, how are we going to have all these activities?  With these IRs, they look at the needs of the society.  If we do not want to look at what the society needs, then it is difficult to have an IR and maintain it.  Furthermore, the Ministers have already mentioned about helping older people to adapt to the new skills.  So I will not talk about this again.  This project will bring more job opportunities. We must train our low-skilled older workers to upgrade themselves in order to take on these new jobs. This will bring about more goodwill in the family.  With the setting up of IRs, the unemployed workers and retrenched middle management executives alike will have better chances to get a new job.  So they can continue to work, save their Medisave and not depend on the children.  If you look at China, India opening up with their middle class expanding, we hope that with these two IRs, we will improve our tourism and bring about more opportunities in other areas and sectors.

     Now, I would like to look at the long term prospect:  what are the IRs going to bring to the Singapore economy?  There are people who ask:  is there no other way? Must we take the casino way?  Of course, what we are taking now is a multi-pronged approach.  We have free trade, transport, medical science, and tourism is just one part of it.  As Minister Lim Hng Kiang puts it, we are sowing the seed with the hope that it would grow into a big tree. It is also like a little flame.  We hope this flame will burn into a much bigger ball of fire and bring about much more vitality, for example, recreation, hospitality, retail, etc.  This will make Singapore alive again.  I hope that we put in as much passion into the other parts of this IR, not only on the casino.

  

   When we talk about entertainment, it can bring about the reinventing of  Singapore.  In the 90s, when the Shanghai Pudong area started reinventing itself, I visited the place and I really feared that

Column: 457

Singapore would become a second class city compared to Pudong. Every time when I go to New York, London, Shanghai or Hong Kong, I could feel the vitality of these cities.  I asked myself, "Are we going to be like a shooting star that just shoots through very briefly?"  Last year, I went to Detroit.  It used to be a very famous town for automobiles.  Now it is a dead city.  I went to Yangzhou which was well known in the past with a lot of historical happenings. But now, Shanghai is the place where most people want to be, and not Yangzhou.  Yangzhou has become a second or third class city, and Shanghai has jumped to the top.

 

     When our foreign friends talk about Singapore, they always say that it is a very clean and beautiful city and it has a very clean and honest government.  These are advantages.  We should not let these pass us.  At the same time, with all these international places, have you heard anyone say that Singapore is a fun place?  A lot of people say that Singapore is boring and full of man-made things.  As advocated by Dr Geh Min, we must have a lot of cultural activities here.  We have to get Singaporeans start all these activities and take in all the international cultures.  For example, I went to Kunming for a meeting.  During the half-day break, I visited the Tourism Board there.  Because I spoke Mandarin, we got on very well.  I asked the official there, "What is Singapore to you? Is there anything that will attract you?"  He said, "Singapore has lost its attractiveness.  If I want to go shopping, I will go to Hong Kong.  If I want to eat nice food, I can go to Bangkok."  So this came from Kunming.  It is not even from Shanghai or Beijing.  Kunming is only a second class city in China.  So I feel that to build an IR with a casino will help to make Singapore into a world-class city with vitality.  We have to look further ahead, and spread the flame far and wide.  I hope that it will be able to

Column: 458

inject new dynamism into our economy and people.

     Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, three years ago, I saw something known as the WOW Singapore idea.  This graceful cultural activity is a new culture.  It does not mean that we must discard our old culture.  It must be based on the existing foundation to flourish and play up the other cultural characteristics that we have from all over the world.  Of course, the project to have an IR is one part of our new culture.  We do not depend entirely on this for our civilisation.  We must use Singapore as the crossroad between the East and the West and as a multi-racial, multi-religious country, we have all kinds of features from all over the world.  Some people suggested that we must have some art galleries in Orchard Road so that they can see the cultural displays along Orchard Road.  There is the lighting up of Orchard Road.  In the Marina Bay, we have a graceful artistic kind of lighting system.  It is like the Bund of Shanghai.

 

     Some three years ago, when I talked about WOW, I praised the lighting system in front of the Fullerton Building.  This is the best that we can see in Singapore so far.  The Singapore River bank and other places can also match those in Hong Kong.  We must allow people to put on neon lights to brighten our city and places of interest.  This should not be considered as unhealthy.  I suggest that we have a competition for the lighting system so that our country becomes more beautiful and attractive at night.  If you go to Shanghai and Hong Kong, if the lights are not turned on, you do not see anything at all.  It is very important.  Mr Goh Choon Kang already commented on this. I hope he would not say that we are wasting our electricity. 

     We have to rebuild Singapore and reinvent Singapore with all kinds of attractions so that we can bring in the crowd, visitors and human dynamism and

Column: 459

night life.  I hope that StarHub will be able to attract investors from other countries to Singapore.  It can be the crossroad or meeting place for the western and eastern cultures and arts.  I hope that world class sporting activities, cultural and artistic activities can be conducted here in Singapore. We should also have our Tiger Beer festival to drink beer.  I have been to Cambodia to take part in a certain activity.  It was not too bad.  Why?  Because one evening I was taken on a night visit and they said it was Tiger Street.  It is a beer street. It is inconceivable that our Singapore brand name of Tiger Street can be hosted in Cambodia.  Why can we not do the same in Singapore? 

 

     In Yunnan, there are all kinds of flower exhibitions.  Why can we not do the same since we are a garden city in the world?  We believe that we have a lot of orchids that we can use for cultural or floral festivals which should be well known in the world.  We can have a lot of things.  We also have a mega exhibition of tropical fishes.  We are the second biggest exporter of tropical fishes in the world.  Why can we not have a similar kind of competition and exhibition in Singapore?  We have been to the great cities in the world, Shanghai, Bangkok, Melbourne, Toronto and so on.  Apart from a lot of high class entertainment centres, they have the Victoria Market, and Sydney has Fisherman's Market and Beijing has the Fisherman Port, and you also have such places in Shanghai.  So I hope that when we are promoting our high class and mega scale exhibitions, we should have, for example, a Little India or Chinatown, to explore the characteristics that we have inherited from different types of culture, so that we will have a lot of world-class possibilities and potentials.  When we explore this kind of mega-projects, we must not forget our cultural heritage.  One Italian friend told me he wanted to set up an Italian restaurant and he spent a lot of money to bring a few gondolas to

Column: 460

Singapore.  Actually, he wanted to ply the Singapore River.  But our officials did not agree to this.  They disapproved this project because gondolas cannot be compared with our tongkangs in the Singapore River.  It is not allowed.  Between China and Japan, you have historical baggage.  But, in Singapore, we can absorb all kinds of foreign talents, foreign restaurateurs and other cultures.  So, we have everything from the world.  Germans have the beer festival, and the Japanese can also have the best restaurants in Singapore.

 

     Sir, I hope that after this debate, we will be able to focus on how to reinvent Singapore so that we can cherish this kind of sentiment and passion, and we will be able to succeed in a big way. 

 

     Mr Ong Ah Heng (Nee Soon Central) (In Mandarin):  Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I support the proposal to build integrated resorts with a casino in Singapore.  I can feel the pain of the unemployed people.  These IRs, with a casino, will be able to create 35,000 jobs.  So, how can I fail to support this kind of proposal?  Losing a job is not the fault of the workers.  They were born into poor families, so they were not able to receive a higher education for better skills to enable them to secure good jobs.  They are part of our country.  They have a family and children to feed.  Although the opening of casinos may cause the breaking up of some families and create some social problems, this is the result of inveterate gambling.  So, it has nothing to do with the majority of our workers.  It is not something that can really be controlled by the Government.  The most important thing is that a lot of our workers are unemployed for a long time.  
 

     Sir, I entirely agree with Minister Vivian Balakrishnan that gambling is already prevalent in Singapore.  But it does not mean that every gambler will go into a frenzy.  Most people do not get into problem with gambling.  I understand

Column: 461

from my constituents that there are two Toto draws a week, three 4-D draws a week, one Big Sweep draw every month, and horse racing two to three times a week. In addition, we have also football matches where you can place your bets on almost every day.  Yes, we have all kinds of legalised gambling going on in Singapore already.

 

     Some of my constituents told me that they can go to Batam and enjoy a free boat ride.  They can go there every day.  They say that a lot of housewives wait for their husbands to go to work and then they would go to Batam to gamble, and come back in the afternoon ahead of their husbands.  So, nobody knows that these women had been to Batam.  Recently, for more than a month, there were some problems that caused the closure of casinos in Batam.  People told me that we can gamble every day in Singapore.  The question is whether you want to gamble and have the money to gamble.  Gambling is going on every day right here in Singapore.  You can play mahjong.  Yes, it is a healthy pastime for many.  At our void decks, we have senior citizens playing card games.  They have nothing to do, so they entertain themselves this way.  We have all kinds of gambling going on right in front of us, day and night.  As shown in the survey done by MCYS, 2.1% of these inveterate gamblers can go underground and gamble, if there is no proper channel for them to gamble.

 

     Some old people told me, "Wherever you have Chinese, you have gambling."  This is what the senior people told me.  Since we have all kinds of gambling going on right here, can we say that our social ethos have already degenerated?  Have our morals also gone down the drain though we are still maintaining the image of being a very clean, moral and honest Government?  We are still getting praises, world acclaim for our image as a clean

Column: 462

and organised society. Gambling is going on not only in Singapore but everywhere in the world.  The question is: how do we control the ill effects of gambling?  Since gambling is so prevalent, then the ills that gambling brings are just  small little problems in our society.

 

     Having heard Minister Wong Kan Seng, Minister Khaw Boon Wan and Minister Vivian Balakrishnan, they have already agreed to set up a safety net in our society.  I would not be as pessimistic as those anti-gambling people.  I can judge from the Ministers' speeches that the social problems created by gambling will not have a very great impact on us.  They are still within control of our social network.

 

     The Shin Min Daily News interviewed some people for their views on the setting up of casinos, and one of them, a 30-year-old lady answered, "Will the opening of a casino lead to bad social ethos and affect our younger children?  I think it depends on the examples set by their parents.  If we teach and educate our children the correct and right values and inculcate these in them properly, then there is no need to worry."  A 25-year-old graduate said, "Unexpectedly, there are two, not one, IRs to be built, but I believe that these two IRs will inject more dynamism into Singapore and will create more jobs for Singapore.  As for the social ills brought about by gambling, I think we are mature enough to control such ills."  These two persons interviewed by the Shin Min Daily News represent our new generation of people.  If there are more young Singaporeans who think like these two persons I have quoted, together with our effective measures to control the ills of gambling and the protective safety net, then the casino will not bring about very serious problems in Singapore.  I think it will be very minimal.  Of course, gambling is bad.  But to some other people, it brings a light of hope.


Column: 463

     Sir, one morning, I went to the dry market at Blk 761 to meet my constituents.  I met one familiar face.  She had just come out from a Singapore Pools betting centre.  I asked her, "You buy 4-D too?"  She said, "Yes.  You buy, then you have some hope.  Otherwise, what hope do the poor people have?"  A lot of people in the lower income group are poor but their ambition is still there.  They do not blame the Government.  They do not blame anybody.  They accept their fate.  But they hope that they will one day strike the first prize in the Toto draw so that they can provide a better life for their children.


     Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I will never oppose gambling, because I know gambling will give some people some hope and the hope to survive.  Big gambling is bad, but small gambling will certainly give some hope to some people.
