     Sir, MM Lee told us that if we continue to remain as the safest, cleanest and the most efficient country or city in the world, then Singapore will miss the opportunities created in the new world.  SM Goh also mentioned that if we do not do anything now, we will be bypassed in no time.  So, the question is:  do we want to seize the opportunities as they come along, or do we want to let others bypass us, and fall behind them?

 

     Sir, Deng Xiaoping's opening up of China and his reforms have already transformed China.  MOS Mrs Yu-Foo went to Shanghai recently and she was very impressed by the spectacular developments in Shanghai.  But we know that the Chinese have already paid a very high social cost.  Do you know how much they have paid socially?  After Prime Minister Lee announced the setting up of two IRs in Singapore, and I went to the coffeeshops in my constituency, everybody put up their thumbs and said "Good".  Is it because they are gamblers?  Is it because they are addicted gamblers?  It is because they do not want the

Column: 464

opportunities to bypass us, because these are the people who are lagging behind the rest of the society, so they will have hope from the casinos.  They believe that the future generation, their children and grandchildren will benefit from this project.

     Sir, when Deng Xiaoping advocated opening up and transforming China, he had not met with any opposition.  Even if there was, he would have succeeded anyway.  So, I would appeal to everybody to put away their differences and give full support to the decision of the Prime Minister.  Even in the dark, we are just like a small boat sailing in the darkness.  No matter how much time we have to traverse the ocean, after the darkness phase, we will see the dawn of light.  We cannot be travelling forever, 24 hours a day, in darkness.  The time of dawn will come.

      Sir, I fully support the Prime Minister's proposal.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the question of having a casino in Singapore has been well

debated in and outside of Parliament and including my home.  My husband and I had stood on the opposite position until the details of the resort concept were disclosed.

 

     I just want to state my position on the casino. To do so, I would like to share a little of our arguments at home.  There were strong religious objections to contrast against a backdrop of supportive reasons that were based on economic values.  In our humble opinion, we perceive these arguments from two platforms:  one from a secular standpoint and the other from a divine or religious perspective.  For me and my family, on the religious perspective based on our faith as Catholic Christians, it would compel us to stand against the setting up of the casino within the shores of Singapore.  However, there is a need to understand that we are living in a secular community of diverse

Column: 465

religions and backgrounds. The arguments for or against the casino must therefore also take on a secular and national perspective on the economics and future of Singapore.  Our argument at home ends in this manner.  For the religious within us, we quote from the Bible, "The human mind plans the way, but the Lord directs the steps."  Let us then allow the "human minds" do our part for the society.  For that, I would support the move to set up an integrated resort and casino.

 

     My reasons are straightforward.  It is a question of economics.  It is about creating jobs for Singaporeans, not 1,000, 2,000 but 35,000 jobs. There is more than the jobs:  the spin-offs from the integrated resorts, world-class architecture and design, development and construction activities, real estate market and values, retail opportunities, services, hotels,  food and entertainment, trade expositions, exhibitions, recreational activities, night life, spending and its multiplier effects, and many others to follow.   The economic spin-offs are immense.

 

    Yes, I am equally concerned with some of the negative impact from gambling addiction, drug trafficking, money laundering and the other social impact on family life in our community.  These are my real concerns.  I am also particularly concerned for the housewives and the retirees. There will be people who will fall prey to glib-tongue racketeers and their fellow travellers.  My fear is that local syndicates may lure these housewives and retirees, using underhand tactics and strip them of their hard-earned savings. They can be enticed into parting with their money under the guise of, say, a sure win bet, or they may be misled by some other quick return schemes. There must be awareness programmes of the dangers of gambling for the housewives and the elderly.

 

Column: 466

     Thus far, from the measures announced by the Government, they are very generic and I hope that there will be special focus groups that will take care of the housewives and retirees, particularly the elderly group.  Our own band of illegal money-lenders will, I am sure, be looking to cash in on the situation, and I urge the authorities to come down hard on them.  Only last week, one young man came to seek for advice.  He borrowed $6,000 from the loan shark and had paid $12,000 over the past six months, but the loan shark is still after him.

 

     As for public education, I am glad that Mrs Yu-Foo has just informed us that MCYS would start the public education now, even before the casino is up.  I believe we should educate the very young who are in our primary school so that when they grow up, they are fully aware of the dangers of gambling.  This will have to be done in earnest and continually reviewed so that it remains relevant to the changing situation.  Grassroots organisations should also be mobilised to use their network to reach out to everyone in the heartlands by holding discussions and forums to explain the pitfalls of gambling and how to stay away from falling into the trap.

 

    I am pleased that the Government is setting up a National Council on Gambling and those who are opponents of the casinos will be invited to sit on the council to advise the Government on measure to mitigate the effects of gambling.

 

     I know in Singapore, we have the infrastructure to tackle some of the scourges related to casino operations. Where we need to, we are beefing up or putting up new Government agencies to look into these issues. I also support the move for an integrated resort because I am confident that the Government, with its well-oiled machinery at its disposal, will put in place the necessary filters to

Column: 467

cushion the negative impact of gambling in our society.

 

     I hope and believe that I am in effect speaking for many Singaporeans when I say:  I too have faith in the strength of our various cultures as well as in our people. We will not be a city of gamblers.  We will not be what we are not.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, like many before me, I too take a practical and realistic view of life.  I do not approve gambling but do enjoy betting on Toto and 4-D occasionally with my friends, staff and my grassroots.  In fact, on many special occasions, my grassroots would want me to pick the numbers of 4-D and Toto because they believe I got some luck.  But so far, the winnings are small.  I do hope that they will strike big one day.

 

    Many speakers before me have spoken on the social ills of gambling.  I share many of their concerns and I will not repeat what has already been said.  I look at this debate from a global perspective and how the future holds for us.  Many speakers, including the Prime Minister, SM and MM, have painted what future directions Singapore should take to avoid becoming a dull and unexciting place. 

 

     When I first entered this House in 1980, Singapore was obviously well ahead of many countries in the region.  In fact, Singapore was an exciting place and our infrastructure was excellent, we have good airports and seaports, we got many visitors. There was less competition from the surrounding countries. China and India were not featured at all.  Malaysians, Indonesians, Filipinos and Thais came here to shop and take in the sights. Tourism was indeed booming.  Our main competitor then was Hong Kong.  Life was simpler then and the tourist demand was less. 

 

     But over the last 10 years, I see changes happening at a very rapid pace.

Column: 468

The Shanghai I visited in 1987 and the Shanghai of today are vastly different.  There are so many modern buildings and highways and the city is buzzing with activities, event happenings and conventions.  Also, I can see changes in Australia; the Opera House and Darling Harbour are star attractions for many tourists. 

 

    Come closer to home is Malaysia.  Only last week, I visited KL and Putrajaya and I can see that the changes that took place in KL and Putrajaya are really remarkable.  The Twin Towers and KLCC complex, with its large shopping malls, convention centres, hotels and even a beautiful park for the busy businessmen to relax in between meetings, were established for them to enjoy.  And I believe KL's night life is very trendy and hot.  So Singapore is no longer that special for the tourists.  It is becoming a stop-over place for the tourists, as mentioned by many in this House.  They would not stay here long. The competition is heating up and Singapore must quickly change to meet the expectations of the modern tourists. 

 

     Yesterday, we heard many speakers mentioning how London changed, how New York changed, how the new iconic buildings in many countries are catching the attention of the modern tourists.  The changing pattern of air travel, including cheap budget airfares, has brought a new dimension to the tourist trade.  There are now many choices and many exotic destinations to go.  So like what the Prime Minister and other Ministers have said, we have to take a critical look at ourselves, at our value systems we hold so dear, our past beliefs, our prejudices and compare them with the future needs of the country.  It is a balancing act but we have to find the right mix.  While we imbibe in new ideas, we have to watch carefully that we do not go overboard.

 

   We have decided to move with the tide of change and bite the bullet and

Column: 469

accept the new changes that are happening around the world.  But there are always consequences. Our Singaporeans were shocked when they heard that there were two instead of one mega integrated resort project.  But I believe the decision was carefully and thoroughly researched.  You can see three Ministries put forward their plans to cushion the possible social ills and security measures to ensure its success.  This shows the determination of the Government to assure Singaporeans that the IR projects could be managed well and 35,000 jobs will be created.

 

     These IR projects are enormous and mind-boggling.  95% of these projects will be theme parks of fun and games, with convention centres, hotels, and only 5% for casino. So why is it that Singaporeans are concerned about the 5% casino element?  One, they are not aware of the other 95% in the first place. They have no idea of what the 95% is going to be like. They have no details. They were merely told.  In fact, some of them were concerned that they have to pay $100 to enter into the complex.  It shows that the communication is not so clear.  In other words, they were not excited enough.

 

     Of course, the media went to town on the casino issue.  So, day in and day out, we read in the newspapers on how casinos are functioning and they only feature the bright lights of the casino. 

But the most important reason is that the casino hits at the very virtues that this Government has always strived for - clean, safe, non-corrupt way of living.  They fear that the casino will change our clean lifestyle and image, and I share their concerns.

 

     At this juncture, I would like to thank the many Singaporeans who emailed me their concerns and fears.  Let me read out an excerpt of one such letter.  It is from a gentleman by the name of Daniel Koh Kah

Column: 470

Soon and this is what he said, and I quote, "Clearly the libertarian/utilitarian consideration has prevailed, but those who hold virtue ethics are saying that worthwhile virtues take a long time to cultivate and nurture.  The virtues, which we have inherited and nurtured should not be eroded by an over-emphasis on libertarian/utilitarian concerns that may allow for vices like gambling to sneak in and undermine time-tested virtues, required and so necessary for any community to flourish as people of good character."

 

     The thrust of his concern is shared by many.  Personally, I think it is good that Singaporeans hold such views.  Yet these virtues, I believe, built and nurtured in the family and Government, should put us in good stead to face the challenges the new Singapore we want to reinvent.  I cannot imagine how the strong character that we have developed over the past would succumb to the temptations for the bright lights of the casinos so easily.  But some may, although the majority will not.  I think the reality of living in a big exciting global city is you have to live with the good and the bad.  How we manage ourselves in the new global city that Singapore wants to aspire is a test of our resolve and strength.  I am sure we are not gullible and naive.

 

     Let me digress a bit to highlight a point.  In the 1980s, in the old Parliament House, there was a heated debate on the report on the healthcare of the elderly.  It was a report written by Mr Howe Yoon Chong, the Health Minister then.  It was a good report, detailing how Singaporeans should examine the problems of the aged and called for many changes to the healthcare delivery system to meet the demands of an ageing population.  But a small paragraph calling for a rethink on the CPF withdrawal at age 55 years was hijacked, and it became the central issue for that debate and the real virtue of that report was thrust aside.  I see some

Column: 471

similarity in today's debate.  So we must be careful.  We must stay on course, explaining and extolling the virtues of these projects and yet detailing and assuring Singaporeans on the measures that we will be taking to cushion the social ill effects, the safety and security aspects of the casino project.  I think this is very important.  This assurance must be given to all Singaporeans.

 

     We must keep to this thrust of argument and let Singaporeans understand the true benefits of the project.  Get them excited through roadshows, and the media should help, and I am sure Singaporeans can come on board with us.  So if anyone wants to hijack the casino element and turn it into a political potato, Singaporeans would have seen the merits of the projects and not be easily persuaded.

Column: 475

Column: 476

MCYS and Health are preparing to deal with the expected problems.

Column: 477

consider having casinos in the IRs.  But all these wonderful attributes are not our soul, but different manifestations of it.  To me, our soul as a society is our collective resolve to remain as an independent and sovereign nation with our distinctive values, multi-racial and multi-religious way of life.

Column: 478

to certain multiples of revenue of other attractions or tourist arrivals to the IRs.  In this way, we will ensure we obtain the anticipated economic spin-offs.

     Sir, in this whole year's long debate, I have been impressed with the openness of the process.  In the Budget debate, I called for a binding referendum even though this is not a life and death issue.  I did that because I wanted the Government to demonstrate clearly that it has not made up its mind and that it seriously considers the views of religious and social groups and others opposed to the idea and are prepared to take a vote on it.  Notwithstanding that, I am glad that this usually efficient Government has been "uncharacteristically inefficient", taking more than a year to come to this decision.  I am glad that the Government has not rushed into this decision.  The deliberations have been worth it.  Like Mr Tan Soo Khoon, I applaud the process of open public consultation.  I applaud the "inclusiveness" of the public consultation, where we listened to every person's view and weigh its merits regardless of his background, race, language, or religion, and in the case of Chia Teck Leng, regardless of his current status or residential address.

Column: 479

heavyweight, bantamweight, etc. But it is also good to acknowledge from time to time that the Cabinet does not have a monopoly on all wisdom, definitely not in this debate, as it is quite clear that Chia Teck Leng has exhibited greater expertise and experience in casino gaming than the Cabinet.  I hope we are witnessing the "greening of Singapore" - whether the Government initiating more public consultations and debates, or people being more willing to express their views and ideas.  This is something a whole generation of thinking and caring Singaporeans have been hoping and waiting for.

    I would urge the Prime Minister and his Cabinet colleagues to share their personal views and feelings on public issues more freely.  In this way, more people will know that their views are being shared by the leaders, considered and deliberated.  There is pluralism in views, but decisions are ultimately made on a rational basis with all these views

Column: 480

taken into consideration.  I believe, in this way, our political fabric will be strengthened and Singaporeans need not fear expressing their personal views, and we will be richer for it.

I applaud the Prime Minister's intention to meet with religious and social groups opposed to casinos in Singapore.  Just like he has persuaded many of us here, I believe that his candour, sincerity and compassion will persuade these leaders that this decision is in the long-term interests of Singapore and all Singaporeans.

     From religious and moral standpoints, gambling is not a good thing.  But if you think in a deeper level, you will realise that the problem is not on gambling but on the people. If people become compulsive gamblers, they will bring about other social problems.  I come from a low income family.  Those around me used to engage in various forms of gaming, such as mahjong, cards, etc.  There were old people who played the four-colour cards and young people who played various games with the poker cards, such as the three old men, blackjack, rummy, and so on.  They also played number games.  Some actually engaged in underground, illegal gambling or 4-D.  Every weekend, a lot of them indulged in horse betting or other games.  From young, I learned a lot about all these games.  When I was younger, I played with cards.  As I grew older, when I was in junior college, I started playing mahjong.  I realised that mahjong is a highly skill-based game.  But it is also very easy for one to get addicted, especially when you are young, you can play it through the night.  Later on, I realised that this was not healthy.  So I decided that I should play not more than eight rounds of the so-called "healthy mahjong". Small gambling is good for temperament, but do not indulge in big gambling.

Column: 482

I was attending the Commonwealth Ministers' Conference and there was a casino at the hotel where we stayed. It was a very far out place and there is no other place to go during our leisure time.  So I took the time between the meetings to take a walk in the casino.  It was not a very big casino.  It was more like a club.  But there were a lot of Chinese there.  In fact, almost all the gamblers were Chinese.  This was because there were a lot of Chinese going there to set up clothes manufacturing factories. I stood near to a table to watch them playing blackjack.  I saw there were three Chinese gamblers.  Lady luck was apparently not smiling at one of them.  He lost all his money and started borrowing from his friends.  Soon, all three of them lost all their money.  I set down and started playing.  In fact, my luck was pretty good. I won about $30-$40.  Then I stood up to go.  The three gamblers looked at me enviously.  They said, "Your luck is so good.  Why don't you continue?"  Of course, I did not continue to play because I knew if I had continued to play, I would end up losing back all that I had  won, and I would lose my own money as well.

     Mr Deputy Speaker, the question is why there are people who get addicted to gambling and why I did not.  For example, Senior Minister Goh and other Ministers have gone to casinos but they did not get addicted.  There are few reasons for that.  First, we all know that the attraction of gambling, whether you are buying 4-D or you are playing on the jackpot machines or blackjack, the odds are not good for the gamblers.  The chances of winning are very low.  I am lucky that when I was in school, we actually learned permutation and combination in our mathematics. We can calculate and hence realise how difficult it is for one to win. Secondly, during my school days, we were taught good values.  There is no free lunch in

Column: 483

this world.  So we have to work hard to make a living.  I am a Buddhist and I know we are not supposed to have greed and to get ill-gotten money.  But there are many other Singaporeans who aspire to have a better life.  I am like them too.

     When it comes to gambling, to me, it is a game.   I know as a fact that it will not bring about great wealth.  For me, small gains are good for the temperament.  I can lose a few dollars, a little bit of money.  That, I can afford.  People oppose the opening of casinos because they believe that people will rush to the casino and become addicted to gambling.  In Geylang, there are brothels and prostitution.  They have been in existence for decades.    Some scientists are studying to find out which part of the gambling brings about the release of dopamine. They used monkeys to do the experiment.  During the experiment, they put a monkey in front of the computer screen and on the screen, you can choose five different designs, just like the jackpot machine. There are some combinations of pictures, and you can win a prize if you strike any

one of them, for example, a mouthful of fruit juice.  Then they found that when there was a certain combination where the monkey could not guess what was coming up next, not knowing what prize it was going to win, the dopamine secretion becomes more.  So if the monkey can guess whether they will win or lose, the dopamine secretion becomes lower.  This means that during expectation and guessing, the stage between the two, the brain is stimulated to secrete more dopamine.  That is how people get addicted.  We need to have some preventive measures.  Of course, the Ministry of Health will set up funds to conduct research in the Institute of Mental Health.  We are very happy to learn that they are going to do this.

and it is this National Council that will advise MCYS on how to allocate these funds to the groups performing its public educational role.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen and Mr Gan Kim Yong stressed the importance of inculcating values and moral education in our young, in building upon what their parents teach at home.  And I echo this.  The National Council on Gambling will work through the MCYS' School Family Education programme and other school-based programmes to reach out to students.  MCYS will also work with the Council to use TV and other media to make sure the message is heard.  But, ultimately, let me tell you, it depends on us as parents, what we say and how we act in front of our children. Just this week on Monday, when I got back, my children discovered that we have now allowed an IR with a casino.  It forced the family discussion on what a casino is and how they should approach it and the dangers.  That same family discussion which I now had to have with my children has to be replicated in the million households in Singapore.  That is our duty as parents.  That is not something the Government can do.  That is not something MCYS can do. 

 

     Why is it so important that parents do it?  Because, ultimately, our children are going to face the casino, whether it is in Singapore or anywhere else in this world.  This is not a pristine, perfect, cocoon world.  Our children will have to face the world and they have to be prepared for it, and preparation is in parental teaching, the inculcation of values and education.  And we should not wait three or four years down the road for an integrated resort to be put up before we start this. This is something which we will have to start, and start now.

 

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen also suggested raising the age limit from 21, I think he mentioned 26 or 27.  Today, as it stands, the age limit for gambling in Singapore is 18.  So by increasing it to 21, we are already setting it at a higher standard.

 

Column: 510

      Many MPs have asked whether the social safeguards will really deter gambling addicts.  Mr Sin Boon Ann, Mr Tan Soo Khoon and Dr Ahmad Magad and in fact many Members said that $100 will not deter a compulsive gambler.  Sir, that $100 levy, or $2,000 a year, is not designed to achieve that.  The entry levy is a signal that gambling is an expense and not a way to make money.  It is meant to deter casual gambling, the office workers in Marina who decide to nip down for lunch to feed the slot machines.  That levy will deter such a person.

 

     If we set it at a higher level, we could.  Some Members have suggested $200, $500 or $1,000.  Let me tell Members how we have arrived at $100, apart from the signalling effect.  We basically did not want to create a situation where the IRs would mean that the casinos are more accessible to Singaporeans than today.  Today, many Members have shared how to go to Batam or Genting.  It would cost you less than $100 upfront.  So by pitching it at that level, it allows me to honestly tell you that we are not making it more accessible.  But let me also tell you that, very frankly, no amount of levy will deter a compulsive gambler.  This is where the exclusion measures come in, and the exclusion measures are tripwires to identify those who are at risk or those who are already addicts, and then to keep them out of the casinos.

 

     Mr Sin Boon Ann also suggested restricting expenditures or even restricting the number of times a Singaporean could enter a casino.  This is something we will study.  But, quite frankly, if we have to micro manage a person to that extent, perhaps you might as well just exclude him in the first place.  My working assumption behind all these safeguards has to be that the majority of Singaporeans can exercise personal responsibility and can manage their finances.  But if you belong to that minority who cannot, either because you

Column: 511

are addicted or because you just cannot be bothered, then you are at risk, we want to identify you and we want to keep you out of the casino.

 

     Many of you have also asked: how will the casino exclusion measures work?  Like most jurisdictions, I said that we will have self-exclusion. But we also know that the self-exclusion system may not be enough because many addicts will not own up to their problems.  The National Council on Gambling will be given the authority, through legislation, to automatically exclude those who are in poor financial situation, bankrupts, poor credit records and those who are receiving financial assistance from the State.

 

     We will empower families, and we have defined them as spouses, children, parents and siblings.  If your loved one has a problem, you go to the National Council on Gambling, inform that you want him to be excluded and the Council will look into this, and if the complaint is valid, then it will invoke its authority to exclude such a person from the casinos.  I recognise that there will be many practical difficulties, and I also recognise that we need to make this process as simple as possible. 

 

     Mr Sin Boon Ann said that it is very hard for family members to exclude his spouse or child, especially if he is grown up.  It can cause family discordance.  Some Members have even talked about family violence.  He has asked that social workers  and community leaders be given the authority instead.  Let me put responsibility where it first belongs.  First, is self responsibility.  If you cannot do it, the next line of responsibility must be the family.  Because, after all, it is the family that has the most to suffer if one member becomes an addict.  Our intention is to emphasise the role of the family in solving problems and to provide a means for the family to signal for help, if the family needs help.

 

Column: 512

     Dr Geh Min suggested that we set up a Tribunal that will conduct hearings similar to a court.  Let me describe to you the system in South Australia.  They have a simple process whereby a complainant lodges an application with the Independent Gambling Authority.  A minimum of two members of the Authority would then interview the complainant, respondent and other relevant persons. This Authority is not bound by the normal rules of evidence and will make a decision.  This has worked well for them so far.  We are thinking of a similar interview process in which we will have a panel which is appointed by the National Council on Gambling.  It will listen to the complaint and make a decision.  If there is an appeal, the appeal will go to the full National Council on Gambling and its decision will be final.  Politicians and Members of Parliament will not be involved in this process.  This will be peer review, wise men and women of society acting to advance the interest and protect the interest of families within society itself.

 

    We want our system to be simple, efficient and a low-cost one so that they will work.  Let me also assure Members, however, in the spirit of consultation, that what I have just put on the table would be subject to further refinements as we consult the family, religious and community sectors in order to improve this further.

 

     Next, many Members have asked: will we relax our safeguards over time? Or conversely, should we increase them now in order to curb problem gambling?  Sir, the social safeguards that we have proposed are already very strict, if not stricter than other jurisdictions.  We will review them from time to time and adopt the best practices that have proven to be effective in minimising problem gambling.  However, we must avoid over-regulation and unnecessarily undermining the

Column: 513

viability of the integrated resort.  So my position on this is clear.

 

     Next question: will we commit adequate resources to tackle problem gambling?  I have already said that the Government is committed to do whatever it takes in order to tackle problem gambling in our society with or without a casino and with or without an integrated resort.

 

     The Deputy Speaker, in his speech, recommended channelling 5% of the casino's gaming tax revenue to fund national programmes.  I do not see the need to ring-fence revenue in this manner.  Funding should be approved on a needs basis, and not dependent on revenue collected.  Because if you opt for that model, then you are well and truly hooked onto the casinos' viability and dependent on the casinos supplying money to the authority that is trying to solve problems.  At this moment, we estimate that we need $40 million annually.  If we need more, I will ask the Minister for Finance for more.  You will have my assurance on that. 

 

     Further, Mr Arthur Fong reminded the House yesterday that every single dollar collected at the entry levy will go to the Tote Board and then it will be spent on charitable causes.  We will not take any of those monies into the Consolidated Fund. 

 

     But, beyond all this, it is worthwhile putting things in perspective, and let us also remind ourselves that gambling is not the only problem or the biggest social problem facing us.  There are many other things that we need to fix, many other things that we need to spend money on as well. 

 

    Next question:  what is the role that the social sector will play in the national

Column: 514

gambling framework?  I announced on Monday that I hope the Family Service Centres and CDCs would play a critical role.  We have not wasted any time.  Tomorrow, the Community Addictions Management Programme (CAMP), IMH and my Ministry will run its first training programme for FSCs and CDCs, not next year.  The objectives of this programme will be to help our staff understand how gambling addictions develop, to be aware of common signs and symptoms, how to screen for problem and pathological gamblers.  For FSC staff, they will be trained to provide basic intervention. 

 

     On Monday, I also said that we would be trying to identify one or two service centres which would serve as specialised counselling centres for problem gambling.  As of today, four centres have already volunteered and we would work with them to enable them to provide this role.  CAMP, MCYS and NCSS will come up with the full training programme for all our staff. And to show that we mean business, as Mayor Othman Haron Eusofe has recommended, we will not flinch from benchmarking our services against international standards.

 

     Another question:  will we do more research?  Yes.  More research is necessary.  We will repeat our baseline study at regular intervals, and we will monitor the trends, and we will share it with this House.

 

     We will also work with CAMP and specialist Family Service Centres to develop a better understanding of local problem gamblers. This will include in-depth studies on issues, such as help-seeking behaviour and the associated problems which they face, and the needs of these affected families.  We need good local data.  This will enable us to put the appropriate education and treatment regimes in place. 

 

     What is our timeline for all this?  On Monday, I said we will set up the National

Column: 515

Council on Gambling in the second half of the year.  Over the last few days, through the email I have already received, several people who are volunteering to serve on this.  I will aim to set up the Council by July or August this year.  The Council can then start work, especially focusing on public education in its initial phases. We will also start equipping our FSCs and CDCs.  And as I said earlier, the training programme begins tomorrow. 

 

     As for building the specialist centres in the community and enacting legislation for the National Council on Gambling, these will take more time to refine.  But we will certainly have to come to the House because it is legislation. 

 

     So let me assure this House that we will keep up the momentum and we will do whatever it takes in good time to deal with the potential problems, which are already here or which may surface in the future.

 

     I am deeply heartened that all MPs, both Opposition and PAP, have agreed that we all need to work together to address the social ills of problem gambling.  I give you this commitment that we will ensure that everyone who needs help can and will get help.  We will put in place in typical Singapore fashion the best framework possible to combat problem gambling.  And in this way, we will ensure that we always remain a good place to bring up our children, have strong families even as we pursue economic opportunities, and even when these opportunities come with some risks.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, point of clarification.  The Minister did not answer my question regarding the counselling services provided by FSCs and medical treatment provided by IMH for problem addicted gamblers.  Would it be free?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Services which are provided in the community by FSCs,

Column: 516

CDCs and the voluntary welfare organisations are heavily subsidised and sometimes free.  But let me actually pin Mr Chia down on this, because the working assumption behind his stand is that, if someone is an addict, it is someone else's fault.  Yesterday, in his speech, he said that it will be the Government's fault because the Government allowed an IR-to-be and, therefore, needs to be compensated.  And his call for free service is really a call for compensation.

 

     Let me put things in perspective.  If you become an addict, you are at fault, and you should recognise that, and you should pay a penalty for it.  Should your family pay a penalty for it?  Regardless of how much help the Government extends, the truth of the matter is that your family will still be affected.  So, let us not run away from this.  Let us not duck responsibility.  Every gambling addict has to own up to his own responsibility and be held accountable for it and pay the penalty for it.  So, let us not get caught by red herrings about whether services will be free and whether compensation will be awarded.  That is the wrong attitude to it.  That would be akin to saying that, because I got photographed with my pants down, I want to sue the manufacturer of the camera for providing such technology.  That makes no sense. 

 

     So, let us put things in perspective.  We will help, but we will not let people duck their responsibilities.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Clarification, Sir.  Does that mean that, for me, or any person who is an addicted gambler who has run into big financial problem because of gambling, he cannot go for treatment in this case because he cannot afford to pay the money for the treatment, or that the family members will have to pay the money for him to get treated?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: We will be very happy to treat him in the Institute of

Column: 517

Mental Health, but we will not bail him out of his financial problems, otherwise he will have moral hazard, and every time someone faces problems, he will declare himself to be an addict and collect the whole lot of freebies which Mr Steve Chia would like to give away.

     Dr Geh Min: Point of clarification with the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports. 

 

     Minister Lim Boon Heng addressed the issue of jobs, especially for the structurally unemployed.  I think that is one of the most compelling, in fact the most compelling, reason for having integrated resorts.  Dr Balakrishnan has also reiterated that point.  My concern is this.  To my knowledge, both integrated resorts and casinos tend to employ young people.  I have not been to that many, but I have asked various people and they confirmed this impression.  So, is the Government going to make sure that they employ the older, less educated workers?  The Minister for Trade and Industry said earlier that the Government has no influence on the IR operators on whether they have a whale or not, and whether they serve foie gras or not.  Let me clarify that at this point my concern is for workers, not the whales.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Dr Geh Min, can you come to your point?  Raise your clarification.

     Dr Geh Min: My point is: can the Government assure us that these integrated resort operators, although they have freedom of choice as to whether they have a whale, can they ensure that it is the workers who need the jobs who will get them, ie, Singaporeans who are structurally unemployed, the old and the less educated?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: We will treat the integrated resort operators the way

Column: 518

we treat all businesses in Singapore, which means whatever rules and regulations or moral suasion which the Ministry of Manpower and NTUC apply on our employers will also apply to them.  This means that the majority of jobs will go to Singaporeans, because they will be subject to the same quotas that apply in the service sector. 

 

     Beyond that, I think these are points which we can discuss in the House, but I do not want to over micro-manage the situation.  If at that point in time we change our rules and our approach to the employment of older workers, then naturally these must apply across the board to all employers.  But this is the subject of a tripartite committee which I believe has been formed between NTUC, the Government and employers.  Let us wait for its recommendations.  The problems of unemployment for older workers is a much bigger and more fundamental one which we need to fix and not just resort to a quick fix.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Prof. Ivan Png.  One last clarification.  I think we have to move on.

     Prof. Ivan Png Paak Liang: Sir, the Ministers have not answered my question, ie, if the operators of the IRs come back and ask for relaxed conditions on admission of Singaporeans, will the Government commit that it will not relax these conditions.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: I said earlier that we would review our conditions from time to time. 

 

     Let me just put things again in perspective.  Why are we doing this?  We are doing this because we want to attract tourists.  If the integrated resorts are unable to attract tourists and they are going to have to depend on locals, we might as well let them go bankrupt.

 

Column: 519

5.52 pm

     The Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, over the last four days, Parliament has had a constructive and very fruitful debate.  The MPs have offered many insights.  They have shared their personal experiences on gambling, whether winning or losing, and stated their positions and concerns.  They have shown their personal convictions and well thought out stands, whether these are for or against the integrated resorts or, more specifically, against the casino component of the integrated resorts.


     It is not the end of our journey, but it is a significant milestone after more than a year of debate.  Now, what we have to do is to make the IRs work -  to yield the economic benefits, to generate the jobs and, and at the same time, to limit the social fallout.

 

     I have tried to explain the process by which we had reached this decision to proceed - how our thinking evolved, why we changed our long-standing policy, what we are still worried about.  Usually, we avoid agonising over policies in public, wringing hands, wondering what to do before we make up our minds.  Our preferred approach is to settle the main lines of a policy, explain the package, and then, if necessary, finetune as we go along, because we do not want to confuse people, we want to present a clear stand, and have the direction we are heading towards more or less worked out.  But in this case, it has been important for us to talk about how we got here, in order to carry people along and understand our thinking.

 

     We have been on a journey.  The Government started out being against the integrated resorts.  We had to review the evidence, confront the facts, rethink our conclusions and, in fact, re-examine our values and predispositions as we found

Column: 520

our way forward step by step, as the phrase goes, feeling your way stone by stone across the river, and gradually crossing the river and reaching a new point.  And to bring the population and the MPs along with us, we had to explain how we got here, how we took these steps forward, why we changed our minds and why we are now here today.

 

     The hardest thing for us to do is to change a policy which is still working.  The problems are not yet obvious; the new policy involves risk and uncertainty; so why not carry on until the problems become more serious?  Maybe we will not have to change.  Whereas if the problem is already on your head and you are already in a deep hole, there is no question you will have to do something about it.  But it is the Government's responsibility to look over the horizon, anticipate problems which are not yet looming large but which are visible in our telescope, and persuade people that we need to change now and to support the necessary change.  So, what we are doing here is to look ahead 10 years, maybe 20 years, a responsibility that the Government takes very seriously.

 

     Our economic policies today are working.  In manufacturing, we are moving up the value added and technology ladder, and going upmarket.  In electronics, bio-sciences, petrochemicals and fine chemicals, the industries are all doing well.  We are getting new investments in research and development.  Our financial sector is doing well, driven by the private banking and fund management industries.   In fact, private banking is growing by 20% per year - the same market, by the way, which the IRs hope to target.  Many more people are coming here from around the region, all the way from the Middle East to China, for education and health care. 


     We are trying to tap the growth of the countries around us and make a quantum

Column: 521

leap in all of these areas.  We want to become a leading centre for high-end manufacturing in Asia.  We want to offer the best education and health services to clients from the Middle East to China, South Korea and Japan; to reinforce our role as a key logistics hub: to entrench our position as a major centre for entertainment and conventions, different from Macao and Las Vegas.  We are not trying to be a strip with 17 or 19 casinos, with flashing lights, tempting sounds and images, but attractive and special in our own way.

 

     We are developing ourselves to become the most cosmopolitan, most open, and also the safest city in Asia, where women and children can walk along the streets all hours of the day and night without fear.  We have to preserve our brand as a well managed city, Asian at its core, but open to change and willing to try bold new ideas.

 

     So, the decision on the IRs concerns the interests of Singapore over the next 10 to 20 years.  It is not a short-term problem.  For the next five years, the IRs are not going to make any great difference to the economy.  Maybe the construction sector will benefit.  But if we do not move now and do not have IRs up and running four or five years from now, by 2009, other countries would have moved ahead, we would have been left behind, and it would be too late to catch up.  You can see where the others are but you are far behind.  In Chinese, we say, wang cheng mo ji, ie, watch the dust and you are not in range to catch up.


     In the short term, we have to overcome some political resistance.  Many Singaporeans are opposed to the idea.  They are not the majority, but they are passionately and sincerely against the idea, and we have to persuade them to accept it or, at least, to let them

Column: 522

understand the reason why we have to move, even though we know they do not agree with the decision. 

     Finally, the Cabinet considered it carefully and we decided we cannot say no, we have to move now. In the long term, the IRs are an essential part of remaking Singapore.  It is a judgement.  Are there downside risks as Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked?  Yes, of course. There are upside risks too. We do not know how it will work out.  Maybe, if it is too successful, we may get frightened of it because it is such an irresistible temptation.  But we have to weigh it and decide the upside and the downside to the best of our ability and judgement. Does it look like it is a good decision for Singapore?  Our judgement, as a Cabinet, is yes, it is a decision which we have to make.

 

    Other countries are already taking note of our move. It is reported all over the regional newspapers, The Herald Tribune has it, the Asian Wall Street Journal has it, the Financial Times has it.  The Malaysians are watching us carefully.  Their media is reporting on this.  Mr Zainul Abidin mentioned this yesterday. They are asking if this is a plus or minus for them. Some people say it is a minus, business will go out.  Some people say it is a plus, because, then, there will be more tourists coming to the region who will visit both Malaysia and Singapore.  Because having visited the integrated resorts in Singapore, why not go visit Genting too?  I watched the Chairman of the Malaysian Tourism Board on television and she took that attitude that it is a plus.  They welcome it. So did the Secretary-General of the tourism ministry in Malaysia.  I think that is the right attitude for neighbours in Southeast Asia to take.


    But the reaction is not just from Southeast Asia. The Chinese are watching us. Shanghai is watching us. The China Daily, which is an English newspaper in

Column: 523

China, devoted half a page of its business segment reporting on our integrated resorts on Tuesday after I made the statement on Monday.  One of our Singapore CEOs happened to be in Shanghai and met the Shanghai government officials.  The officials told him, "Singapore, while small, has made such a tremendous impact regionally ... This decision [talking about the IRs] is another example of long-term planning that will no doubt improve Singapore business stature."  So they are watching us. They are studying which way we go and I have no doubt that they are asking themselves, "Is it something which we should consider?  If so, when should we move?"  Because Shanghai has moved forward on many fronts and, in some areas, they are well ahead of Singapore, and this is not something unthinkable.


    I am convinced that the majority of MPs and, I believe, majority of Singaporeans, support the idea of an integrated resort.  I draw this conclusion based on the debate these last few days, my soundings with MPs and their grassroots, and feedback I received myself, visiting the constituencies, talking to the grassroots leaders and their residents. There is support for it.  And after the debate and the explanations in the House, I am confident that the support level will go up.  But the basis for this decision is not the popularity of the proposal, otherwise we could have done a straw poll or referendum, as Dr Loo Choon Yong suggested, and then gone with whatever the straw poll said.  The right basis is what is right for Singapore in the long run. That is what we have to judge and decide.

 

     Most MPs who have spoken disapprove of gambling, or, at least, they disapprove of excessive gambling. Some oppose it because of their upbringing, like Mr Arthur Fong, whose father left him an indelible experience, or their religious faiths, like Mr Loh Meng See, who spoke

Column: 524

just now. Some oppose all forms of gambling, because of personal experiences of family members who are gambling addicts. And when you have gone through such an experience, that also leaves an indelible impression on you, and you say, "I do not want this ever to happen.  Let there not be such an evil on the earth."  Others have done their calculations and found that gambling is pointless because the house always wins, as the Minister Mentor explained. 

 

    Some of the shrewdest and wealthiest businessmen in Singapore do not gamble. They could be a whale if they wanted to, but they think it is foolish, and a waste of money.  Mr Ong Beng Seng is one of them.  I have got his permission to tell you his story.  He said that he found out that the house always wins. So he must have played and eventually concluded that it is a mug's game, the player always loses.  So he had a solution.  He decided to be on the other side. He bought the house, and later sold it for a good profit. The shrewdest businessmen, the ones who are smartest at making money, will tell you, "If you want to make money, this is not the way to do it."  This attitude towards casinos and gambling is a good one.  I do not believe that having the integrated resorts will shift this basic attitude.  This is an attitude and is the immune system in our society which will inoculate us against succumbing to excessive gambling.

 

    But we also have to be realistic. Even without IRs, many people are already gambling, as Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon and Mr Ong Ah Heng pointed out just now. They work with the unions so they know the ground, people's habits and how they behave.  The MCYS' survey confirmed what we knew - 58% of Singaporean adults gamble.  But what was interesting was also the amounts which they gamble.  Median expenditure per gambler per month is $83; average is $244.  If you base it on one year, the median

Column: 525

expenditure is almost $1,000 and the average is nearly $3,000.  This is what an average gambler in Singapore will spend.  Most of these will be social and recreational gamblers, but a few will get into trouble.

 

     I am not a gambler myself.  I have been lucky.  I have not experienced the problems of gambling, either me or my family.  My family does not gamble.  I was going to tell you all about my non-gambling occasions, but they paled in comparison with Senior Minister's and other stories which the House has heard, but I will just tell you one.

    On a rare occasion, we were at a very serious meeting in Canberra in 1989, the first APEC Conference, and it happened to coincide with the Melbourne Cup.  I was there with George Yeo. Everything came to a stop.  This was in the middle of the day. The Prime Minister, then Bob Hawke, flew from Canberra to Melbourne to attend the race, congratulate the winner and come back to Canberra the same day to receive us at dinner.  We had to stop doing business because the whole country ground to a halt.  All the Australian staff and officers were going to watch, so we had better watch too.  Our attitude was, if we are going to watch, we might as well put some money on it.  So we passed the hat around. This being APEC, we decided on a collective bet, 12 countries. It was not a big sum, so we bet one horse.  My job was to name the horse. We chose the "Empire Rose".  I cannot remember why, but I remember the name - there was a profound political reason.  It lost. That has not been an indelible lesson, but it is a vivid example of how difficult it is to be smarter than the other guy and smarter than the house.  So never believe that one can gamble to earn a living or to get rich.   I have seen in MPS,

Column: 526

families who are in trouble because of gambling, just as I have seen in MPS families who are in trouble because of other reasons, drinking or just being dissolute or unable to manage their finances.  It is very sad and every case you see is one case too many.

 

    Like everybody else, I would like to protect our people and our own children from ruining their lives through gambling.  But I do not believe we can solve the problem by banning gambling.  I also do not believe that gambling is something which we can completely outlaw.  We take that attitude with drugs.  There is no such thing as recreational use, whether it is cannabis, heroin, cocaine. For consuming drugs, you go to jail or the drug rehabilitation centre.

    But we do not take that attitude with other social vices.  We do not ban cigarettes, which are extremely harmful. All we can do is to tax them heavily so, at least, some public good comes out of a private addiction. You can also become addicted to alcohol, which can break up families and ruin lives.  But we do not ban alcohol, because that does not work.  We allow alcohol to be sold, and we tax it.  And there is such a thing as a social drinker - you drink wine or beer, it is part of socialising, it is normal. Muslims do not. Some other people feel that they do not want to, but drinking is accepted within society.

 

    Prostitution is a sin. It is wrong, but it is a reality. As the MM explained, we are a port city, if we do not allow it, you drive it underground.  So we allow it, we regulate it, we have a system of health checks, and everybody knows the even numbered Lorongs are different from the odd numbered Lorongs. 

    Gambling opportunities now are far more prevalent than they ever used to be.  It is a fact of life. We have to accept it.  Cruises to nowhere are common.  Singaporeans go, grassroots leaders go, and MPs go with them because it is part of

Column: 527

bonding amongst the grassroots. And the MPs tell me that when you go on a cruise to nowhere, before you can cross the international boundary, there is a queue outside the casino. The moment the doors open, people rush in. If you were not there and you were eating a chicken wing at a buffet, and you hear the PA system announce, "The doors are now open", you will drop your chicken wing, half-eaten, and run. 

 

    On the Internet, gambling is available readily.  You do not have to visit the sites, the sites visit you.  Because you may be at some perfectly innocent site and up it pops and says, here's a casino, try your hand at black-jack, or whatever it is, with bright flashing lights - a private casino in your own home.  I was doing some research - I assure you - a few days ago, preparing for this debate and up came a site. So I decided to click on it. The site is called popebetting.com because a new Pope was being elected, and here is the chance for you to put some money on the candidates.  There was a whole listing of the cardinals and the odds, the first one of which was Cardinal Ratzinger, 3:1.  I regret I did not click on the next link.  So the temptation is all around you.  You have to teach people how not to gamble excessively and we have to have safety nets to catch and treat those who become gambling addicts.

 

     We have to get our people to learn, and particularly the next generation to learn, that it is stupid to think of gambling as a way to get rich.  If you have to gamble, treat it as a consumption item, and set a budget to spend.  If I am going to have a fling this evening, here is $50 or $100 I am going in with, that is what I am going to spend. When it runs out, I go home.  It is like going to the movies or on a holiday.  It is spending money.  If you lose, do not try to earn it back. That is disastrous, as Chia Teck Leng found out.  I have had very intelligent, very well

Background

 

     This is not a new idea.  In 1999, the Nurses and Midwives Act provided for the setting up of a Nurse Specialist Register.  The objective was identical.  It was to promote the development of nurse specialists who can, through formal training, acquire the necessary knowledge, skills and competencies to play a greater role than that traditionally performed by nurses.  Over the years, some of our nurses have, on their own efforts, acquired such expertise and many more have expressed an interest to pursue such advanced training.

 

     My Ministry encourages this trend.  First, it raises the status of the nursing profession.  Second, it recognises and maximises the potential for some nurses to take on added responsibilities.  With proper training, such nurses can competently perform tasks like: physical assessments of patients; ordering and interpreting diagnostic tests; and initiating treatment according to an approved protocol.

 

    Internationally, such a development is not new. In the US and the UK, such a category of clinical nurses has evolved over 30 years to become an important player in their healthcare systems. 

Column: 539

Increasingly, they have also switched to call such nurses "Advanced Practice Nurses" instead of "Nurse Specialists".   

 

    This Bill will essentially update and amplify the existing provisions in the Nurses and Midwives Act, which pertain to the certification and regulation of nurse specialists.  In so doing, we shall re-name nurse specialists as "Advanced Practice Nurses (APNs)", in line with international nursing nomenclature.

 

Benefits of APNs

 

    APNs bring benefits to patients, doctors and nurses.  International experience suggests that APNs are effective in initiating management of common acute illnesses and injuries.  APNs are also valuable in managing stable chronic conditions with particular emphasis on health promotion and disease prevention.  They can promote better patient compliance with treatment.

 

     Many studies have been conducted to gauge the quality of care provided by APNs. Early studies found that in an appropriate setting, patient care and outcomes were of equivalent quality to that provided by doctors, and patients were satisfied with their care. More recent studies have shown that APNs' intervention and care contributed to shorter length of stay, fewer hospital admissions, reduced re-admission rates and therefore healthcare costs.

 

    Such outcome studies confirm the positive impact of APNs and establish them as cost-effective caregivers of quality healthcare.

 

     For doctors, the services provide by APNs complement their care.  This makes APNs useful partners. APNs' extended scope of practice allows them to take on some of the routine duties of the junior doctors. This frees up the junior doctors

Column: 540

to spend more time on patients who require their higher level of expertise.   

 

     As an example, in primary healthcare setting, APNs can work with family physicians to manage nurse-led follow-up clinics for patients with chronic diseases. They can also conduct patient education and counselling sessions which will include re-enforcement of self-management skills, emphasis on medication compliance and evaluation of treatment.

 

     For the nursing profession, the APN Register opens up an alternative career track to allow experienced and skilled nurses who have the necessary advanced qualifications to remain in clinical setting without compromising their career development. This is one way to retain good nurses in the profession.

 

     To prepare for this development, the National University of Singapore started its "Master in Nursing" programme in 2003.  This was a milestone in local nursing education.  It launched our APN training programme. The first batch of 14 graduates will complete their one year internship next month. They will then be eligible for appointment as APNs.

Advanced Practice Nurses
